questionList.questionText: A 31-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, is brought to the emergency department by her husband due to heavy vaginal bleeding.  She is at 30 weeks gestation by a last menstrual period and has not received prenatal care.  The patient has had heavy vaginal bleeding for the past 2 hours, soaking through a pad every 30 minutes.  Her last pregnancy ended in an uncomplicated term vaginal delivery at home.  Vital signs and fetal heart rate tracing are normal.  A transvaginal ultrasound reveals a complete placenta previa.  After conservative management, the vaginal bleeding stops.  The findings and management, including a cesarean delivery, are discussed with the patient and her husband.  The patient says she does not want a cesarean delivery because she would like to deliver at home again.  Which of the following is the most appropriate statement?
questionList.explanationText:
Most medical decision-making considers the patient's preferences and values, which are then used to determine the best treatment option.  However, when there is only 1 safe, reasonable treatment option with clearly superior evidence, physicians should perform directive counseling and assume an active role in guiding therapy.

This patient has a complete placenta previa, in which the entire cervical os is covered by the placenta.  This completely obstructs fetal delivery and can lead to unexpected, often unprovoked, heavy vaginal bleeding.  Although low-lying placentas and partial placenta previas may resolve with time (due to upward expansion of the lower uterine segment, which pulls the placenta toward the fundus), complete placenta previas are highly unlikely to resolve.  Therefore, vaginal delivery is contraindicated due to imminent maternal (eg, hemorrhage) and fetal (eg, intrauterine demise) morbidity and mortality.  The only safe option for delivery is cesarean delivery.

Currently this patient's bleeding has stopped; she is not in active labor; she does not require immediate delivery.  When the time comes for delivery, the patient has the right to accept or refuse cesarean delivery (ie, patient autonomy takes precedence).  However, it is still the physician's ethical duty to advise against vaginal delivery and provide directive counseling by explaining why cesarean delivery is medically necessary.

(Choices A and E)  Patients have autonomy to make decisions against medical advice.  However, even if the patient agrees to the risks of vaginal delivery, the physician cannot condone this life-threatening option (eg, "I will allow").  Endorsing half-measures (eg, "You can choose to have a vaginal delivery, but I recommend that you come to the hospital") is also misleading, and bargaining with the patient is inappropriate.  The only ethical recommendation in this situation is cesarean delivery, and the physician should practice directive counseling with this patient.

(Choice C)  Assisted decision-making, in which family members help make decisions, is not required in this situation because the patient's husband's preference for mode of delivery does not change the need for cesarean delivery.

(Choice D)  The risk of repeat hemorrhage in patients with placenta previa is highest following an initial bleeding episode.  Therefore, decision-making should not be delayed in case another life-threatening bleed occurs.

Educational objective:
When there is only 1 safe, reasonable treatment option, physicians should perform directive counseling and assume an active role in guiding therapy.  Physicians should explain to patients with complete placenta previa that cesarean delivery is medically necessary.
questionList.subject: Obstetrics & Gynecology
questionList.title: Informed consent

answerChoiceList.choice: "A vaginal birth can cause serious bleeding and harm to the baby, but if you understand and agree to these risks, I will allow you to deliver at home."
"I will only recommend a cesarean delivery, because vaginal delivery puts your life and your baby's life at risk."
"I'll give you some time to discuss this with your husband, so you can make a decision about your preference together."
"We can discuss this again in a few days after you have had more time to weigh your options."
"You can choose to have a vaginal delivery, but I recommend that you come to the hospital so we can help you if something goes wrong."

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Prevalence of antepartum hemorrhage in women with placenta previa: a systematic review and meta-analysis.
Placenta previa, placenta accreta, and vasa previa.
Committee opinion no. 664: refusal of medically recommended treatment during pregnancy.

questionList.questionText: A 29-year-old primigravida at 36 weeks gestation comes to the office with her husband for a routine prenatal visit.  Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated, and she has no chronic medical conditions.  Her only medication is a daily prenatal vitamin.  Vital signs are normal.  Fundal height is 36 cm, and fetal heart sounds are 150/min on Doppler ultrasound.  The patient says she has created a detailed birth plan and would like to have a natural delivery.  She says a vaginal birth is necessary for her to feel fully connected to her baby, and she is not interested in receiving any medication that would decrease the pain.  The patient's wishes are acknowledged and documented in the chart; however, the physician states that unexpected events can occur during labor and delivery that may require a cesarean delivery.  The patient replies, "A cesarean delivery is not part of my birth plan—I don't want to have one."  Which of the following is the most appropriate response?
questionList.explanationText:
Although this patient has expressed her wishes for a vaginal delivery, it is the physician's duty to inform her that unexpected complications can occur in normal pregnancies that may necessitate a cesarean delivery to protect both her and her fetus.  By conducting a thorough informed consent discussion in advance (an example of preventive ethics), the physician has the opportunity to explain the indications for an emergency cesarean delivery and review the risks and benefits in an unhurried, unpressured atmosphere.

Routine prenatal care visits present an ideal setting for conversations addressing planned and potentially unanticipated delivery situations and necessary interventions (eg, emergency cesarean delivery); such conversations serve to optimize shared decision-making and prevent future misunderstanding and disagreement.  When reviewing potential treatment needs in advance, the informed consent process should include a clear description of the specific circumstances in which a cesarean delivery would be indicated, in addition to a comprehensive overview of how a cesarean delivery is performed.  This allows the physician to address the patient's specific reservations about cesarean delivery and take time to answer any questions she may have.

(Choices A and E)  These responses shut down the conversation based on the physician's preferences while dismissing the patient's own concerns and rationale for her objections; they also threaten her with abandonment or a potential procedure against her will.  In contrast, the process of shared decision-making respects the patient's values and priorities and would more effectively open her to receiving education on vaginal versus contingent cesarean delivery.

(Choices B and D)  While it is important to recognize patient autonomy, the physician may be able to address the patient's concerns to reach agreement about when a potentially life-saving cesarean delivery would be acceptable to her.  Therefore, it is premature to merely document a decision without first understanding the patient's reservations, providing adequate education relevant for the decision-making process, and specifically discussing the indications for cesarean delivery.

Educational objective:
Routine prenatal care should include an informed consent discussion that anticipates clinical complications necessitating a cesarean delivery.  This process should include a clear description of indications, risks, and benefits as well as an opportunity to address the patient's specific concerns and questions.
questionList.subject: Obstetrics & Gynecology
questionList.title: Informed consent

answerChoiceList.choice: "Cesarean deliveries may be unavoidable in an emergency.  Let me refer you to another provider that may be more comfortable with your birth plan."
"Given how your pregnancy is progressing, a cesarean delivery is unlikely.  We'll discuss this again only if it is absolutely needed."
"I would recommend a cesarean delivery only if it were absolutely necessary.  Let's talk about what the indications would be."
"It's your right to refuse a cesarean delivery if you do not want one.  I'll make sure to document your preference in the chart."
"My priority is to take care of you and your baby, so if the baby is in distress during labor, I will need to do a cesarean delivery."

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Informed consent and shared decision making in obstetrics and gynecology: ACOG committee opinion, number 819.

questionList.questionText: A 16-year-old girl comes to the office with her parents for evaluation of depressed mood.  While being interviewed privately, she reports feeling "down and useless" ever since being cut from the soccer team 3 weeks ago and says, "I'm not good at anything; what's the point of even trying?"  The patient reports decreased energy but no changes in concentration and maintains average grades at school.  She smokes "a little bit" of marijuana to help her fall asleep at night.  The patient has no significant medical or psychiatric history.  Vital signs are within normal limits.  Weight has decreased by 3 kg (6.6 lb) since her last visit 6 months ago.  Physical examination shows superficial scars in different stages of healing on her upper arm and inner thighs.  When asked about this, the patient responds, "I cut myself superficially when I'm upset, which helps me feel better.  Sometimes I think it would be easier if I were dead, but I don't have the courage to really hurt myself."  The patient would like to start treatment but asks that the physician not tell her parents any details about the visit.  Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questionList.explanationText:
Adolescent nonsuicidal self-injury

Features

  • Deliberate injury with no intent to die
  • Methods: cutting, burning, scratching
  • Typical onset: age 12-14

Function/purpose

  • Regulate distressing emotions
  • Punish self
  • Elicit support or allow for avoidance (eg, missing school)

Management

  • Psychotherapy
  • Psychiatric evaluation, medications for comorbid conditions

Confidentiality vs safety

  • Consider informing parents if any of the following are present:
    • Suicidal ideation
    • Impairment, distress
    • Multiple episodes, escalating frequency
    • Single episode with serious medical risks (eg, use of razor, sutures)

This patient has symptoms of depression (eg, feeling down, low energy, difficulty sleeping, weight loss, thoughts of dying) and shows evidence of cutting behavior.  Adolescents often engage in cutting behavior to alleviate distressing negative emotions.  When this is done without the intent to die, it is referred to as nonsuicidal self-injury.  Although NSSI is not performed with suicidal intent, these patients are at increased long-term risk for suicide attempts as well as bodily harm, and early intervention is essential.  The decision to break confidentiality must balance autonomy and treatment rapport while maintaining patient safety.

Exceptions to maintaining the confidentiality of minors include the following:

  • Suicidal or homicidal ideation or potentially dangerous self-harming behavior
  • Abuse
  • Neglect

In this case, the patient has symptoms of depression, has expressed thoughts about death, and shows evidence of multiple episodes of superficial cutting, creating reasonable concern for her safety.  The patient has no active intent or plan to kill herself, making immediate hospitalization unnecessary; however, parental involvement is necessary to protect her from future harm.  The best approach is for the physician to explain why disclosure is needed and to engage the patient in informing her parents.  Options for disclosure include calling the family with or without the patient present and offering to remain present while the patient contacts her family.

(Choice A)  It is best to involve the patient in the process of disclosure to the family.  Family support is an important part of treatment, and helping to build communication skills among family members is beneficial.  In addition, approaching the family without the patient's input would likely damage her sense of trust and willingness to be open in the future.

(Choice B)  Although parental consent for antidepressant treatment is required in some states, notifying the parents for this purpose is premature because treatment recommendations have not been discussed.  Parental notification is generally not required for a general mental health concern unless it poses a serious safety threat; parental notification is required when there is concern for self-harm.

(Choice C)  Due to multiple episodes of self-injury coupled with depressive features and thoughts of death, informing the parents is necessary.

Educational objective:
Exceptions to maintaining the confidentiality of minors include suicidal ideation and potentially dangerous self-harming behavior.  Ideally, adolescents should be involved in creating a plan to inform their parents.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Patient confidentiality

answerChoiceList.choice: Directly inform the patient's parents about her depression and self-harming behavior due to concern about her safety
Directly inform the patient's parents about her depression because their consent is required for treatment
Do not breach confidentiality and schedule frequent follow-up to closely monitor the patient
Involve the patient in creating a plan to inform her parents about her depression and self-harming behavior

questionMappingReferencesList.title: I thought you said this was confidential?-challenges to protecting privacy for teens and young adults.

questionList.questionText: An 8-year-old girl is admitted to the hospital for relapsed acute myeloid leukemia.  Based on a recent bone marrow analysis, the patient requires aggressive treatment that includes multiple chemotherapeutic drugs and bone marrow transplant; chance of survival after 5 years is 20%.  She is cared for by her mother, father, and maternal grandmother, who moved in with the family to help with her care.  After extensive discussions among the family members and the physician about treatment options and prognosis, the girl states that she does not want to be treated.  She is behind in school; she says that the treatments make her feel terrible, and she wants to go home to have more time with her friends.  The patient's parents appear to understand their daughter's concerns but want treatment started immediately.  On examination, the patient is alert and interacting appropriately with no remarkable findings except for generalized pallor.  Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Exceptions to informed consent by parent/guardian in minors

Emergency care

  • Condition in which treatment delay
    can cause serious impairment or death 

Emancipated minor
(adolescents)

  • Parent
  • Married
  • Military service
  • Financially independent
  • High school graduate
  • Homeless

Specific medical care
(adolescents)

  • Sexually transmitted infection
  • Substance use disorder (most states)
  • Pregnancy care (most states)
  • Contraception

Informed consent is required for all medical care except for immediate, lifesaving interventions (eg, emergency intubation).  Minors (age <18) have medical decision-making power only in certain medical situations that allow for confidentiality (eg, contraceptive care) and in legal scenarios that grant emancipation (eg, married, active military).  In all other circumstances, including this case, a parent or guardian is responsible for providing consent.

Assent, defined as agreement with treatment, is ideally obtained from a minor but is not required to proceed with treatment.  By around age 7, children typically can make logical decisions, and minors' involvement in their medical care should match their level of developmental maturity, with an increasing role during adolescence.  If a child refuses to assent, an open discussion is advised to emphasize the importance of pursuing the treatment plan decided on by the parent or guardian.  As a minor, this patient's decision-making capacity does not affect the treatment plan because her parents are responsible for medical decision-making (Choices A and B).

(Choices D and E)  Requesting additional input from extended family members or from an ethics committee is not necessary because the parents have already agreed to treatment.  An ethics committee is particularly useful when parents do not consent to treatment that may be in the best interest of their child.

Educational objective:
Parental consent is required prior to providing nonemergency medical care for a minor who does not qualify for confidential care (eg, pregnant) or is not emancipated (eg, married).  Assent from the child is ideal but not required to proceed with treatment.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Ethical principles in healthcare

answerChoiceList.choice: Follow the patient's wishes and arrange supportive care
Have the patient evaluated for decision-making capacity
Proceed with treatment as discussed with the family
Request additional input from extended family members
Schedule an ethics committee meeting to reach consensus

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Informed consent in decision-making in pediatric practice.

questionList.questionText: A 40-year-old man with type 2 diabetes, obesity, and nonalcoholic steatohepatitis comes to the office for follow up.  Over the past year, the physician has initiated appropriate pharmacotherapy for the patient's diabetes and emphasized dietary changes and weight loss to treat the patient's fatty liver disease.  However, the patient has been unable to lose weight and his most recent liver function tests and liver biopsy show worsening disease.  The patient recently heard about a clinical trial testing a novel pharmaceutical treatment for fatty liver disease and asks the physician if he should enroll, stating that he cannot lose weight on his own and wants to get the best treatment for his disease.  The physician is one of the principal investigators for the study and confirms that the patient meets eligibility criteria.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next action by the physician?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient has nonalcoholic steatohepatitis, which has progressed despite appropriate treatment (eg, lifestyle modification, antidiabetic medication).  He is now considering participating in a clinical trial in hopes of obtaining better treatment.  The patient's belief that participation in a clinical trial offers a direct therapeutic advantage (eg, access to advanced superior treatment) is known as a therapeutic misconception and should be addressed before the patient enrolls in the research study.

In contrast to the goal of clinical practice, which is to offer the best available treatment for an individual patient, the purpose of clinical research is to advance scientific knowledge for future populations of patients.  Therefore, in clinical trials, participating subjects may not receive superior treatment for the following reasons:

  • The superiority of the experimental treatment is not yet established, and it may be found to be inferior, ineffective, or harmful.
  • The participant may be randomly allocated to a treatment (or control intervention) that is eventually found to be inferior.
  • In placebo-controlled trials, the participant may receive an inactive or inert medication.

Therefore, before enrolling the patient in the trial, the physician should counsel the patient that he may not receive direct benefits from the trial.

(Choices A and C)  As an investigator (a role that should be disclosed to the patient), the physician is likely highly knowledgeable regarding the novel treatment and able to explain its known risks and benefits.  However, the patient should not be encouraged or discouraged to participate; rather, the physician should provide objective information about the trial (including how it is conducted) and allow the patient to decide for himself whether to participate.  Furthermore, he should not be encouraged to participate based on the potential benefits of the novel drug because he may be randomized to the control arm of the study and not receive it.

(Choice B)  Although patients who enroll in clinical trials may need to withhold outside treatment for the condition under study, they should otherwise be encouraged to continue normal care with their regular physician.  This is true even if the regular physician is also an investigator in the trial, although procedures and documentation between the trial and clinical care should be carefully segregated.

Educational objective:
Therapeutic misconception refers to a patient's belief that participation in a clinical trial will offer access to superior care.  Participants in clinical trials should be counseled that they may be allocated to a treatment for which the benefits are not yet established, may eventually be found to be inferior, or is inactive or inert (ie, placebo).
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Research ethics

answerChoiceList.choice: Describe the novel pharmaceutical treatment and encourage the patient to participate in the trial
Disclose the physician's role as primary investigator and explain that the patient will need to seek care elsewhere if he participates in the trial
Disclose the physician's role as primary investigator and recommend participation as it is in the patient's best interests
Explain how clinical trials are conducted and that the patient may not receive direct therapeutic benefit

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Enrolling research participants in private practice: conflicts of interest, consistency, therapeutic misconception, and informed consent.

questionList.questionText: A 28-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to a lump on his right arm.  The patient reports, "It has been there for several years, but in the last few days, it has started moving and talking to me."  He has a history of schizophrenia that has responded well to olanzapine.  The patient has been admitted to the psychiatric floor twice in the last 12 months for psychosis due to medication nonadherence.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 156/92 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min, respirations are 16/min.  On examination, the patient is alert and oriented to self, place, and time but keeps looking at his right arm and talking to it.  The speech is pressured and confused at times.  A soft, mobile, nontender, 2-cm mass is noted on the posterior surface of the right forearm.  There is no surrounding warmth, erythema or fluctuance.  The patient asks the physician to get close to it so he can hear it talk and again asks for it to be removed right away.  Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questionList.explanationText:
Assessment of decision-making capacity

Criterion

Patient task

Communicates a choice

Patient able to clearly indicate preferred treatment option

Understands information provided

Patient understands condition & treatment options

Appreciates consequences

Patient acknowledges having condition & likely consequences of treatment options, including no treatment

Rationale given for decision

Patient able to weigh risks & benefits & offer reasons for decision

This patient with schizophrenia is acutely psychotic, and his thought process and judgment are currently influenced by delusions and hallucinations regarding his lump.  Although he wants the lump removed, his reasoning is based on delusional ideas.  For informed consent to be valid, a patient must demonstrate decision-making capacity.  In his current condition, this patient lacks capacity because he is unable to understand his condition, appreciate the consequences of treatment options, or weigh the risks and benefits of the surgical procedure in a rational manner.

When decision-making capacity is impaired by reversible factors (eg, psychosis, delirium), the next step is to treat the underlying cause with the goal of restoring decision-making capacity.  In a nonurgent situation, as in this patient with a possible lipoma (eg, soft, mobile, nontender mass that has been present for years), the next step in management is to defer his request to remove the mass and treat his acute psychosis with the goal of improving his decision-making capacity.

(Choice B)  Reassurance is unlikely to be effective, and it is inappropriate to ignore the patient's request indefinitely.  Once his psychosis is treated, his decision-making capacity regarding surgical removal of the mass should be reassessed.

(Choice C)  Obtaining consent from the next of kin as a surrogate decision-maker would be appropriate only if the situation were urgent and/or the patient's mental status were unlikely to improve.  In this patient, removal of the mass is not urgent, and the patient's acute psychosis is likely to improve after he is prescribed antipsychotic medication.

(Choice D)  This patient currently lacks capacity to consent for removal of the mass.  His decision-making capacity needs to be reassessed once antipsychotic medication has taken effect, which may take days to weeks.

(Choice E)  Capacity can be assessed by any physician who knows the risks and benefits of a treatment or procedure.  In this patient, lack of capacity has already been established (ie, he is unable to understand his condition due to the influence of delusions and hallucinations).  A psychiatric assessment for the purpose of assessing capacity is unnecessary.

Educational objective:
Valid informed consent for nonurgent treatment requires intact capacity.  When the patient's decision-making capacity is impaired by reversible factors (eg, acute psychosis), it should be restored by treating the underlying cause.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Decision making capacity

answerChoiceList.choice: Administer an antipsychotic medication and defer the request to remove the mass
Decline to perform the procedure and reassure the patient that the mass is benign
Obtain consent from the patient's next of kin prior to removing the mass
Remove the mass as requested by patient and administer an antipsychotic
Request a psychiatric assessment for decision-making capacity

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Assessment of healthcare decision-making capacity.
Treatment decision-making capacity in hospitalized patients with schizophrenia.

questionList.questionText: A 32-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, at 42 weeks gestation is admitted to labor and delivery for spontaneous rupture of membranes and contractions.  The patient's pregnancy has been uncomplicated, and she has no chronic medical conditions and takes no medications.  Blood pressure is 120/60 mm Hg, pulse is 78/min, and respirations are 12/min.  Fetal heart rate monitoring shows a baseline of 130/min, absent variability, and recurrent late decelerations.  Intrauterine resuscitation with maternal repositioning and oxygen administration does not improve the fetal heart rate tracing.  The cervix is 4 cm dilated and 25% effaced on digital cervical examination.  The patient is informed of the need for an emergency cesarean delivery due to significant risk for fetal asphyxia and death.  However, she refuses to undergo cesarean delivery.  Further discussion reveals that the patient fully understands the risks of refusing the procedure and continues to insist on a vaginal delivery.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questionList.explanationText:
This laboring patient has a category III fetal heart rate tracing (ie, absent variability, recurrent late decelerations), a sign of fetal hypoxemia that, if sustained, may lead to fetal demise.  Patients with category III fetal heart rate tracings are typically managed with emergency cesarean delivery.

Patients have the right to make their own medical decisions as long as they understand the risks and benefits of the procedure (ie, have capacity).  Such decisions can become more complicated in the setting of pregnant women, as both the mother and fetus are affected.

However, until delivery, the mother has complete autonomy for medical decisions affecting both herself and the fetus, including refusal of treatment (even if this leads to adverse fetal outcomes).  In these scenarios, the rights of the mother are considered over those of the fetus (Choices A and B).  Therefore, the most appropriate next step is to respect the patient's decision and continue with vaginal delivery.

(Choices D and E)  Seeking a court order or an alternative decision maker (eg, spouse, parent) may be necessary for patients who lack capacity for their medical decision-making.  This patient understands the risks and benefits of refusal of treatment.

Educational objective:
Pregnant women with capacity have the same right to refuse treatment (eg, emergency cesarean delivery) as nonpregnant patients, even if the decision does not represent the best interests of the fetus.
questionList.subject: Obstetrics & Gynecology
questionList.title: Decision making capacity

answerChoiceList.choice: Proceed with emergency cesarean delivery because the fetal rights are more important than the patient's autonomy
Proceed with emergency cesarean delivery because there is evidence of fetal distress
Respect the patient's decision and proceed with vaginal delivery
Seek a court order forcing the mother to undergo emergency cesarean delivery
Seek out an alternative decision maker

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Committee Opinion No. 664: refusal of medically recommended treatment during pregnancy.

questionList.questionText: An 81-year-old woman comes to the office for follow-up of type 2 diabetes mellitus, which has been well controlled on a stable medication regimen for several years.  Medical history is notable for hypertension and osteoporosis.  Six months ago, she suffered a nondisplaced orbital fracture.  She is widowed and has lived with her daughter and son-in-law for the last year.  She claims that she is independent and "takes care" of herself.  Blood pressure is 176/102 mm Hg and pulse is 84/min.  Examination shows bruising at the right forearm and right flank.  No cardiac murmurs are heard.  Abdominal examination is unremarkable.  Gait is steady and the patient does well on the Timed Up and Go test.  Laboratory results show a fasting glucose of 220 mg/dL and hemoglobin A1c of 9%.  Four months ago, glucose was 105 mg/dL and hemoglobin A1c was 7.2%.  On further discussion, the patient says, "The pharmacy charges me too much these days.  I just can't afford my medication anymore."  Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's clinical findings?
questionList.explanationText:
Elder abuse

Risk factors

  • Female
  • Dementia, chronic mental illness
  • Functional impairments
  • Social isolation
  • Shared living environment
  • Poor socioeconomic status/financial stress

Manifestations of abuse

Physical & sexual abuse

  • Atypical abrasions, lacerations, contusions, fractures
  • Pain not consistent with reported etiology
  • Anogenital injuries
  • Newly acquired STI

Psychological & verbal abuse

  • Change in behavior/personality
  • Depression/anxiety

Neglect

  • Inadequate nutrition or hydration
  • Pressure injuries
  • Deterioration in comorbid conditions

Financial exploitation

  • Failure to adhere to medication regimen
  • Multiple missed appointments
  • Unpaid expenses or rent payments

STI = sexually transmitted infection.

This patient has findings that raise concern for elder abuse, including multiple injuries and an acute change in financial status (ie, discontinuing longstanding medications due to cost), possibly due to diversion of finances by family members.  Abuse is most common in older women, especially those who are socially isolated or have a shared living environment (ie, live with multiple nonspousal others).  Dementia and chronic mental illness also increase the risk.

Manifestations of physical abuse in the elderly are similar to those in younger patients, and may include unexplained pain, injuries in multiple stages of healing, or injuries in unusual locations.  Although osteoporosis increases the risk of fracture with minor trauma, orbital fractures (as in this patient) are atypical.  Elderly individuals are also at risk for financial exploitation, psychological abuse, sexual abuse, and neglect.  Most jurisdictions require that suspected abuse be reported to adult protective services or other governmental agency.

(Choice A)  Late-onset alcohol abuse is more common in elders who live alone.  Living with multiple family members increases the risk for elder abuse.  Elder abuse is also more likely to explain this patient's injury pattern (orbital fracture, multiple bruises in unusual locations).

(Choices B, D, and F)  Dementia, affective disorders, and psychotic disorders are common in elderly patients and can lead to nonadherence to medical therapy.  However, this patient has experienced multiple injuries that suggest abuse.

(Choice E)  Nutritional deficiencies are usually seen in elders who live alone and do not have outside nutritional support.  Although a variety of vitamin deficiencies can cause bruising, this patient's orbital fracture is more suspicious for abuse.

Educational objective:
Manifestations of physical abuse in the elderly may include unexplained pain, injuries in multiple stages of healing, or injuries in unusual locations.  Elderly individuals are also at risk for financial exploitation, psychological abuse, sexual abuse, and neglect.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Elder Abuse & Neglect

answerChoiceList.choice: Alcohol abuse
Early-stage dementia
Elder abuse
Late-life depression
Nutritional deficiency
Psychotic disorder

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Elder abuse.

questionList.questionText: A community hospital affiliated with a nearby academic medical center is opening a new intensive care unit.  The unit will be staffed by residents and a critical care attending during the day and by a hospitalist at night; the physicians will be supported by a team of specially trained critical care nurses and respiratory therapists as part of a larger multidisciplinary team.  Most of the supplies will be provided by the academic medical center, and the new unit will accept patient transfers from the academic center during the day.  Which of the following tools will likely be most helpful in systematically mitigating potential errors before operations begin in this new unit?
questionList.explanationText:
Failure mode and effects analysis (FMEA) is a systematic, team-based approach that consists of identifying steps in a process and finding solutions to any problems that may arise, with the goal of ensuring safe outcomes.  FMEA is a prospective process that can be performed before problems occur, as in this case of an intensive care unit (ICU) that has not yet opened.

The first steps involve assembling a multidisciplinary team (eg, physicians, nurses, respiratory therapists); defining the FMEA topics (eg, ventilatory alarm malfunction, bedsore development); and graphically describing the processes within each topic (eg, flowchart).  Failure modes, which are all the things that could go wrong in each process (eg, ventilator alarm does not go off when it is supposed to), should be identified.  A hazard analysis should then be conducted, identifying and documenting:

  • Any possible effects of each of the failure modes (ie, anything that could happen if the failure actually occurs), classified based on severity

  • Any potential causes of each of the failure modes

The probability of occurrence of these causes should be estimated, which allows for the development of a hazard decision matrix to classify the failure modes.  For each failure mode, an action plan should be developed to address it if it occurs.

Using FMEA, multiple potential problems can be identified in advance along with possible solutions, thereby helping mitigate the effects of errors once the new ICU opens.

(Choices A and D)  Control charts and root cause analysis (RCA) are quality improvement tools that are useful once processes are in place and a problem is identified.  Compared to FMEA, these approaches have a more limited role prior to the opening of the ICU.  Control charts plot the data of a variable over time along with upper and lower control limits within which the variable should be located (eg, monthly infection rates in an ICU); values that consistently fall outside the upper control limit, for example, signal a potential problem that should be evaluated.  RCA is a rigorous approach generally put in place in reaction to an event (rather than prospectively), with the goal of identifying underlying causes.

(Choice C)  A near-miss ("close call") is when a negative outcome could have occurred but did not, either by chance or due to timely intervention (eg, a provider orders penicillin for a patient with a penicillin allergy, but the medication is not administered because the patient's nurse notes the allergy and alerts the provider about the error).  As with control chart analysis and RCA, near-miss analysis is performed retrospectively and would not be applicable for this ICU that has not yet begun operations.

Educational objective:
Failure mode and effects analysis (FMEA) is a prospective, systematic, team-based approach that consists of identifying steps in a process and finding solutions to any problems that may arise, with the goal of ensuring safe outcomes.  FMEA can be performed before any problems are identified.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Patient safety

answerChoiceList.choice: Control chart analysis
Failure mode and effects analysis
Near-miss analysis
Root cause analysis

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Failure mode and effects analysis for proactive healthcare risk evaluation: a systematic literature review.

questionList.questionText: A 27-year-old woman comes to the office to discuss weight loss.  She has gradually gained weight since she was married 6 years ago.  The patient says, "I have tried every diet I know, and nothing seems to work.  There must be something wrong with me."  Medical history is unremarkable.  She has 2 children and does not use tobacco or alcohol.  Vital signs are within normal limits.  BMI is 28 kg/m2.  Physical examination shows an overweight body habitus and is otherwise normal.  Which of the following is the most appropriate response to this patient's concerns?
questionList.explanationText:
Behavioral interventions for weight loss

Stimulus control

  • Maintain stocks of easy-to-prepare, healthy foods
  • Store healthy foods in prominent locations
  • Limit stocks of less healthy foods

Physical activity

  • Moderate-to-intense aerobic exercise
  • Resistance/strength training
  • Lifestyle activity (eg, take stairs, reduce sitting time)

Self-monitoring

Regular documentation of:

  • Weight
  • Food intake
  • Exercise

Accountability/

follow-up

  • Provider visits, phone calls, Internet contacts
  • Group participation sessions

This patient is overweight (ie, BMI 25-29.9 kg/m2) and has been gradually gaining weight over the years.  During this time, she has been unsuccessful in losing weight using various diet programs.  A number of weight-loss diet programs (eg, low-fat, low-carbohydrate, blended low-calorie) have proved to be effective in clinical trials, but application by individual patients is commonly met with inconsistent success.

Regardless of the specific diet chosen, successful weight loss can be enhanced by incorporating behavioral strategies into the overall program.  In particular, detailed self-monitoring of dietary intake, exercise, and daily weight is associated with increased success rates.  Self-monitoring is also associated with greater long-term maintenance of weight loss.  Although some patients fear that daily weighings may lead to frustration and less weight loss, most studies have not found this effect in practice.

(Choice A)  Overweight and obese (BMI ≥30 kg/m2) patients commonly experience weight gain beginning in their 20s, regardless of marital status or childbearing.  Although this patient's weight gain began after marriage, there is otherwise no indication that family stress is the cause of it.

(Choice B)  Exercise should be included in a broader weight loss program because it is associated with greater weight loss and better long-term maintenance.  However, exercise alone is not generally effective for weight loss.

(Choice D)  Weight-loss medications are recommended for patients in whom conservative measures have failed and whose BMI is ≥30 kg/m2 or ≥27 kg/m2 with additional weight-related conditions (eg, diabetes mellitus).  However, the costs and potential adverse effects of these medications are not typically justified for otherwise healthy, overweight patients.

(Choice E)  Screening for secondary causes of weight gain (eg, hypothyroidism) and weight-related complications (eg, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia) should be considered for overweight and obese patients.  However, most overweight patients have normal thyroid function and should not be given false hope that they have an easily correctable condition in the absence of additional clinical signs.

Educational objective:
Successful weight loss can be enhanced by incorporating behavioral strategies into the overall program.  Detailed self-monitoring of dietary intake, exercise, and daily weight is associated with increased success rates.  Self-monitoring is also associated with greater long-term maintenance of weight loss.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Obesity

answerChoiceList.choice: "Family stress is a common cause of weight gain.  Let's talk about how that might be affecting you."
"I can see how this is frustrating to you.  Instead of dieting, I think you should try an exercise program to lose weight."
"There are many reasons why weight-loss diets might not work.  Let's start by keeping a daily diary of your weight and food intake."
"There are several medications that can help you lose weight.  Let's talk about the pros and cons."
"You most likely have a thyroid disorder.  Let's run some basic tests before we try any more diets."

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Log often, lose more: electronic dietary self-monitoring for weight loss.
What matters in weight loss?  An in-depth analysis of self-monitoring.

questionList.questionText: A previously healthy 9-year-old boy is evaluated for a deep puncture wound to the foot.  He was walking barefoot on the beach when he stepped on a rusty nail.  His parents cleaned the wound with soap and water and applied pressure to it.  The boy takes no medications.  He has not received any vaccinations due to parental preference.  The boy's parents are divorced and have joint custody of him.  The indications, benefits, and risks of tetanus vaccination are discussed with both parents.  The mother consents to the proposed tetanus vaccination and requests that it be administered immediately.  However, his father refuses to agree to the vaccination as he prefers to explore herbal remedies.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Exceptions to informed consent by parent/guardian in minors

Emergency care

  • Condition in which treatment delay
    can cause serious impairment or death 

Emancipated minor
(adolescents)

  • Parent
  • Married
  • Military service
  • Financially independent
  • High school graduate
  • Homeless

Specific medical care
(adolescents)

  • Sexually transmitted infection
  • Substance use disorder (most states)
  • Pregnancy care (most states)
  • Contraception

This patient is an unemancipated minor, defined as an individual age <18 years who requires consent by a parent or legal guardian for medical or surgical treatment.  In all states, minors may receive acute care without consent if obtaining it would delay treatment.  The parents or legal guardians must be notified as soon as possible.  Many states also allow minors to consent without parental notification for contraception, treatment of sexually transmitted diseases, prenatal care, mental health services, and substance use rehabilitation (Table).

According to the American Academy of Pediatrics Committee on Bioethics, a parental decision to decline routine immunization for an unvaccinated child is often tolerated as the risk of acquiring infection in a community with herd immunity is relatively low.  In contrast to elective vaccination, this patient is at high risk of tetanus infection from the deep puncture wound and administration of tetanus vaccination is urgent.

In patients with divorced parents, only parents with custody may give consent for medical care.  Parents with joint custody are each able to consent, but consent from only one parent is all that is necessary to proceed with treating the minor, especially when the decision is clearly in the child's best interests.  In all cases, treatment is ideally discussed with both parents to reach an agreement that will help the child and facilitate cooperation between the treatment team and the parents.

(Choice A)  Unemancipated minors do not have the legal authority to consent for procedures; consent must be obtained from at least one parent.

(Choice B)  It is appropriate to consult the hospital's ethics committee if an ethical dilemma is present.  This is not the case with this patient as tetanus vaccination is in his best interest and the mother has already provided consent.

(Choice C)  If both parents refuse to consent to life-saving treatment, the physician would need to seek court approval before administering necessary but nonurgent treatment (eg, chemotherapy for acute lymphoblastic leukemia in a stable patient).

(Choice E)  Withholding the proposed treatment is inappropriate as the mother has already consented, which is considered legally sufficient to proceed.  Parents cannot deny their children life-saving treatment unless the benefits are minimal or would not alter the prognosis.

Educational objective:
When caring for an unemancipated minor, informed consent from one parent or guardian is considered legally sufficient to justify proceeding with therapy.  Physicians should also provide care in urgent situations without waiting for parental consent.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Informed consent

answerChoiceList.choice: Ask the patient about his wishes and proceed with his decision
Consult the hospital’s ethics committee
Obtain a court order to proceed with the proposed treatment
Proceed with the proposed treatment
Withhold the proposed treatment

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Childhood immunization: when physicians and parents disagree.
Consent for emergency medical services for children and adolescents.

questionList.questionText: A 64-year-old woman is undergoing right knee replacement due to advanced osteoarthritis.  The orthopedic surgeon who is performing the surgery is well known to the patient and has managed her symptoms for several years.  On the day of surgery, the orthopedic surgeon and anesthesiologist obtain informed consent from the patient.  During intubation, the anesthesiologist lacerates the tongue, causing extensive bleeding that obscures the airway.  Multiple attempts to secure the airway are unsuccessful.  An otolaryngologist in the adjacent operating room is urgently consulted and performs an emergency tracheostomy.  Which of the following best describes the nature of this incident and the way that it should be disclosed to the patient's family?
questionList.explanationText:
Tongue laceration is a rare but potentially serious adverse event (ie, iatrogenic injury not due to patient underlying disease) associated with endotracheal intubation.  The resulting bleeding can be severe, requiring emergency tracheostomy.  Although the risk can be reduced (eg, by using fiberoptic intubation for high-risk patients), tongue laceration can occur, even with appropriate preparation and physician experience.

When multiple physicians are involved in a patient's care, cooperative disclosure of a serious adverse event to the patient or family is recommended.  This practice increases transparency (ie, accurate exchange of information) and achieves the following objectives:

  • Promoting continuity of care and reassuring the patient and family that all the physicians are working for the patient's well-being

  • Offering a unified and coordinated explanation of the error and next steps (eg, consistent explanation of events, expectations for recovery)

  • Facilitating an efficient response to patient or family questions and concerns (eg, all team members are present to provide information relevant to their area of expertise)

  • Promoting a culture of safety (eg, safety as a collective goal) rather than a culture of blame (eg, attributing error to an individual)

All physicians involved in this patient's initial care (eg, anesthesiologist, orthopedic surgeon) and in the response to the adverse event (eg, otolaryngologist) should collectively disclose the adverse event to the family (Choice B).

(Choices C and D)  A near-miss event is an error caught before patient injury occurs (eg, incorrect medication is ordered but not administered).  Patient injury occurred in this incident, which is better described as an adverse event.

(Choice E)  A negligent event is an adverse event arising from a clear violation of standards of care by an individual.  Tongue laceration is not necessarily a negligent event and can happen even when proper care standards are followed.  Based on the information given, this incident is more accurately characterized as an adverse event.

Educational objective:
When a serious adverse event occurs during treatment, all physicians involved in the patient's care should collectively disclose the event to the patient and family.  A cooperative discussion can increase transparency, promote continuity of care, and facilitate an efficient response to patient and family questions and concerns.
questionList.subject: Surgery
questionList.title: Patient safety

answerChoiceList.choice: Adverse event; the anesthesiologist and both surgeons should meet the patient's family together to disclose the incident
Adverse event; the anesthesiologist and otolaryngologist should meet the patient's family together to disclose the incident
Near-miss event; the anesthesiologist and orthopedic surgeon should meet with the patient's family to disclose the incident
Near-miss event; the anesthesiologist should meet with the patient's family to disclose the incident
Negligent event; the anesthesiologist should meet with the patient's family to disclose the incident

questionMappingReferencesList.title: What constitutes appropriate team communication after an error?

questionList.questionText: A 72-year-old woman with a history of diverticulitis and obesity is admitted for elective sigmoid resection.  Postoperatively, an epidural catheter is placed for pain management.  The patient is followed by a primary team including house staff who rotate on a 12-hour shift-based schedule.  During the night, a cross-covering intern manages the team's patients.  On the evening of postoperative day 3, the patient experiences new, intermittent right leg pain and tingling.  The nurse pages the cross-covering intern, who is assisting in an emergent rapid response event on another patient.  He evaluates the patient's leg pain several hours later and concludes the pain is likely a temporary reaction to pain medication.  The next morning during signout to the primary team, the intern forgets to mention the patient's leg pain.  A few hours later, the patient reports new chest discomfort.  As the primary team is evaluating the patient, the patient suddenly enters pulseless electronic arrest and dies.  Postmortem examination reveals pulmonary embolism.  Which of the following interventions is most appropriate to prevent this error?
questionList.explanationText:
Errors related to transfers of care

Definition

  • Adverse patient outcomes due to changes in responsibility of patient care
  • Can occur in clinical setting (eg, shift change, transfer between departments) or post-discharge

Root causes

  • Suboptimal communication (omitted or vague information) between providers
  • Excessive distractions during signout process
  • Lack of standardized signout protocols
  • Documentation errors (eg, outdated medication list, no documentation of cross-cover events)

Preventive strategies

  • Implement standardized signout communication (eg, checklists or mnemonics)
  • Avoid vague instructions (eg, "follow-up x-ray"); communicate specific action plans
  • Conduct signout communication in quiet environment
  • Add redundancy (eg, separately documenting cross-coverage events in addition to verbal signout communication)
  • Ensure accuracy of information in written signout

Errors related to transfers of care (changes in responsibility of patient care) within the hospital primarily result from miscommunication (vague or omitted information) during signout (patient-related information exchange between providers).  In this case, omitted information (ie, patient's overnight leg pain) likely prevented the primary team from further workup and identification of deep venous thrombosis prior to the patient's fatal pulmonary embolism.  Judgment errors (eg, cross-covering provider's failure to recognize the patient's deep venous thrombosis risk factors) related to care transfers are also common, as new providers are less familiar with patients compared to the primary team.

Protocols requiring separate documentation of cross-coverage patient events can prevent errors related to omitted information during signout.  This approach introduces redundancy (a patient-safety strategy incorporating repetitive, "back-up" modes in a process to protect against human error) to verbal signout.  A separate progress note documenting the patient's leg pain would have alerted the primary team to the event despite the intern's omission during signout communication.

Additional best practices to reduce communication errors during signout include:

  • Standardized signout process (eg, mnemonics or checklists) to ensure essential information is consistently and systematically discussed for each patient

  • Specific action plans in lieu of vague directions (eg, "give 20 mEq of oral potassium chloride if serum potassium <4.0 mEq/L" instead of "follow up potassium")

  • Quiet environment for signout to minimize distractions

  • Closed-loop communication (ie, receiver confirms receipt of message and repeats it back to the sender) to ensure accurate comprehension of action items; however, this would not prevent errors of omitted information, seen in this case (Choice E).

(Choice B)  Psychological safety describes team members' comfort in expressing safety-related concerns and questions without fear of intimidation.  This intern's omission of information reflects human error rather than conscious fear.

(Choice C)  Transparency, a principle of safety culture, describes organizational awareness and disclosure of safety-related information and incidents.  This adverse outcome resulted from erroneous physician-to-physician communication during signout, not lack of transparency.

(Choice D)  Removing shift-based scheduling is not currently recommended due to significant safety risks of provider fatigue associated with extended work hours.

Educational objective:
Communication breakdown during signout (eg, omitted information during handoff between providers) is a leading cause of transfer-of-care errors and can be prevented with standardized signout processes (eg, checklists, mnemonics) and redundancy (eg, separate documentation of cross-coverage events).
questionList.subject: Surgery
questionList.title: Patient safety

answerChoiceList.choice: Implementing documentation protocols
Improving psychological safety
Increasing organizational transparency
Removing shift-based schedules
Training in closed-loop communication

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Rates of medical errors and preventable adverse events among hospitalized children following implementation of a resident handoff bundle.
Consequences of inadequate sign-out for patient care.

questionList.questionText: A 44-year-old woman requests a same-day appointment due to poor sleep.  The patient says that when she goes to bed, her "brain can't shut off" and she feels "too wired" to fall asleep.  She has been spending hours online, shopping and playing games.  The patient established care at the clinic 12 years ago and has a long history of bipolar disorder.  Medications include valproate and ziprasidone.  Vital signs and physical examination are normal.  On mental status examination, the patient is animated, laughs frequently, and speaks rapidly.  She has no suicidal ideation, hallucinations, or delusions.  Treatment recommendations are discussed, and the patient is agreeable to increasing the dose of valproate and starting clonazepam for sleep.  A follow-up visit is scheduled for 1 week.  At the close of today's visit, the patient expresses thanks and presents a gift of sterling silver pens to the physician.  Which of the following is the most appropriate response?
questionList.explanationText:
Accepting gifts from patients raises complex issues.  Some physicians decide to adopt a no-gift policy.  Others maintain that gifts of low value, given with no expectation of preferential treatment, are acceptable or that rejecting the gift can damage the physician-patient relationship.  In the absence of absolute guidelines, most physicians decide whether to accept a gift on a case-by-case basis by considering multiple factors.  Cost, type, and timing of the gift; the apparent motivation behind giving it; and the nature and longevity of the physician-patient relationship all factor into the decision of whether to receive a gift (Choice A).

In this scenario, the primary concern is the patient's impaired mental state influencing her decision-making.  She has bipolar disorder, and her difficulty sleeping, racing thoughts, elevated mood, excessive online spending, and pressured speech are concerning for a manic episode that may have compromised her judgment.  The physician must consider that this patient's gift may have been purchased within the context of diminished reasoning due to her manic state.  Therefore, regardless of cost, the gift should be politely declined while expressing appreciation for the offer ("Thank you for thinking of me . . . but I am unable to accept this gift"), and the rationale for the refusal should then be clearly explained (eg, "I am concerned your condition is influencing your decisions").

(Choice B)  Understanding the intent of a gift may be helpful in determining whether inappropriate motivations exist (eg, to secure preferential treatment) or in assessing a patient's mental state.  However, in this scenario, the patient shows evidence of mania; asking for her rationale would not change the physician's initial obligation to politely decline the gift.

(Choice C)  Sharing patient gifts of nominal value (eg, baked goods, chocolates) with office staff is acceptable.  However, it is inappropriate for a physician to accept a gift that was likely purchased because of a patient's impaired mental state.

(Choice E)  Physicians should both ensure and clearly communicate that accepting (or declining) gifts will not alter the patient's level of care.  However, because of this patient's condition, it is not appropriate to accept the gift.

Educational objective:
Decisions about whether to accept gifts from patients include the cost, type, and timing of the gift and the patient's motivation for giving it.  Gifts should never be accepted from patients experiencing a mood episode that could be altering their judgment.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Professional conduct

answerChoiceList.choice: "I appreciate the effort you put into this, but physicians are not allowed to accept gifts from patients."
"I'm sorry I can't accept this, but I would like to understand more about why you decided to bring a gift today."
"Thank you for such a nice gift.  I will make sure to share these with the office staff."
"Thank you for thinking of me.  I'm happy to take care of you, but I am unable to accept this gift."
"Thank you for this thoughtful gift, but please understand that it does not affect the care you receive."

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Is it ethical to accept gifts from patients?

questionList.questionText: A large tertiary care hospital in a major metropolitan area experiences a series of fatal medication errors involving excess doses of heparin in neonates.  Multiple internal quality investigations reveal that, in addition to the medication errors, the hospital has experienced a higher-than-average frequency of near misses and adverse patient events involving diagnostic errors, iatrogenic infections, and documentation errors.  A new chief medical officer is appointed and convenes an interdisciplinary quality and patient safety committee.  The committee subsequently develops strategic recommendations to address the hospital's high incidence of adverse patient events.  Which of the following committee recommendations is most likely to increase organizational safety and reduce the risk of patient harm?
questionList.explanationText:
Systems approach to error prevention

Overview

  • Address organizational environment & teams
  • Emulate high-reliability organization practices (eg, aviation)

Components

  • Culture of safety: prioritize safety-promoting resources
  • Resilience: systems design to prevent errors
  • Team-based vigilance: safety oversight by entire team
  • Comprehensive analysis: avoid simplistic explanations

Examples

  • Human factors engineering: reduce human effort needed for safe action
  • Swiss-cheese model: multiple overlapping layers to block errors ("holes")

Errors that cause serious patient harm (eg, fatal medication errors) occur with unacceptable frequency in health care settings.  To improve patient safety, health care systems can emulate high-reliability organizations (HROs) (eg, aviation industry).  These organizations minimize catastrophic errors despite operating in complex, high-hazard environments like health care.  HROs build a culture of safety through a systems approach to error prevention.  This approach is characterized by:

  • Resilience to error:  This approach views human error as inevitable in complex settings and designs workflow processes (eg, standardization, adding double-checks) that anticipate and minimize the consequences of such errors (eg, preprogrammed dosing limits on a drug infusion pump that minimize the potential patient harm from a staff member accidentally entering an excessive drug dose).

  • Comprehensive analysis:  This approach avoids simplistic explanations for errors (eg, focusing only on individual personnel).  It carefully examines all factors, including latent factors (eg, system-level vulnerabilities) (Choice D).

  • Team-based vigilance:  This approach assigns safety oversight responsibilities to all individuals; each team member continuously monitors for errors and may speak candidly without fear of retaliation (Choice B).

(Choices A and E)  Although clear organizational goals and attention to individual effort (eg, vigilance, monitoring) are required for safety, even careful individuals may make errors in complex, distracting environments.  Therefore, organizational goals of zero human errors are unrealistic, do not address errors latent within systems, and can promote a culture of fear.  Instead, organizations should set goals of zero adverse events (ie, no harm to patients) that can be facilitated through systems and processes that reduce, not increase, reliance on human effort (eg, reduce reliance on memory by using checklists and standardized processes).

Educational objective:
Human error is inevitable in complex environments such as health care.  The incidence of adverse patient events can be reduced by designing systems and workflow processes that anticipate and correct human error to minimize the adverse consequences to patients.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Patient safety

answerChoiceList.choice: Create workplace environments that increase reliance on human effort for correct action
Delegate safety oversight responsibilities to a specific group of health care personnel
Design workflow processes to minimize the consequences of incorrect actions
Perform event analyses routinely to identify personnel who are involved in errors
Promote clear organizational goals that target zero human errors in high-risk settings

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Evidence brief implementation of high reliability organization principles.
Value of human factors to medication and patient safety in the intensive care unit.

questionList.questionText: Administrators at an academic medical center are interested in implementing a rapid response system to improve management and health outcomes of inpatients who experience sudden clinical deterioration, such as cardiac arrest.  The system involves an interprofessional rapid response team (RRT) that is called by the patient's primary team to assist in patient care by regularly monitoring, triaging, and stabilizing high-risk patients.  Hospital guidelines recommend that primary teams involve the RRT when patients display early clinical warning signs (eg, prolonged tachycardia, tachypnea).  Shortly after implementation of the rapid response system, a nurse is concerned about an elderly patient's sustained tachycardia.  However, she is hesitant to call the RRT because the attending hospitalist has previously expressed reservations about the measure, stating:  "I've been doing this for over 20 years, and I know how to manage my patients best.  The more people that get involved, the greater the chance that the hospital will hold me responsible for someone else's mistake."  The behavior of the nurse and the hospitalist indicate a need to address which of the following?
questionList.explanationText:
Psychological safety refers to team members' comfort in taking necessary and appropriate actions for safety (eg, openly expressing concerns, recruiting help).  Psychological safety promotes effective teamwork and is an essential feature of high reliability organizations (eg, high-risk industries such as aviation that require excellent safety records).

The effectiveness of this hospital's rapid response team (RRT) depends on appropriate engagement by the primary team.  Hospital guidelines indicate that this patient's prolonged tachycardia should prompt RRT involvement.  However, the nurse and hospitalist demonstrate resistance toward this action, demonstrating low psychological safety:

  • The nurse hesitates to voice her opinion that the RRT should be involved.  This can occur in the presence of strict hierarchy (ie, perceived differences in authority levels), which causes fear of retribution (eg, punishment, blame) if contrary opinions are expressed.

  • The hospitalist expresses concerns about RRT involvement and being held responsible if an error happens likely due to a culture of fear, which can occur when organizations overemphasize incorrect individual actions over systems factors.

Psychological safety can be improved by organizational initiatives including increasing transparency (eg, feedback and communication), dedication of additional resources to safety, and change management (eg, engaging personnel in designing and adopting new safety initiatives).

(Choice A)  Closed-loop communication (ie, receiver repeats back message relayed by the sender) improves accuracy of verbal exchanges but does not address fear to communicate caused by low psychological safety.

(Choice B)  Although some clinical decisions require independent decision-making, the hospitalist's reluctance to engage in recommended team-based activities is suboptimal and should be addressed by improving psychological safety.

(Choice D)  Cognitive bias describes mental shortcuts used in clinical decision-making (eg, fixation on an initial diagnosis without careful consideration of alternate possibilities).  Fears of retribution and blame are more representative of psychological safety issues.

(Choice E)  The hospital has already established standard guidance for RRT involvement, but low psychological safety hinders practical adoption by primary teams.  Moreover, RRT involvement does not involve formal transitions of care but instead represents joint patient management.

Educational objective:
Psychological safety refers to team members' comfort in taking actions (eg, openly voicing concerns, asking for help) for safe patient outcomes.  Psychological safety is hindered by strict hierarchy or fear of retribution and can be promoted by organizational initiatives such as change management (ie, engaging front-line personnel in improving organizational culture).
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Patient safety

answerChoiceList.choice: Improving interprofessional closed-loop communication
Prioritizing independent decision-making among health professions
Promoting psychological safety within the hospital culture
Reducing cognitive bias among physicians and nurses
Standardizing processes involved in transitions of care

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Exploring psychological safety in healthcare teams to inform the development of interventions: combining observational, survey and interview data.
A systematic review of factors that enable psychological safety in healthcare teams.
Evaluating implementation of a rapid response team: considering alternative outcome measures.

questionList.questionText: On the third day of a surgical sub-internship, a fourth-year medical student is invited by the chair of the department to observe the operative repair of a congenital heart lesion on a 4-year-old girl.  A team of multiple providers is present in the operating room, including a surgical scrub nurse, anesthesiologist, and surgical resident.  As preparations are made to begin the procedure, a team member places a Foley catheter into the patient.  The medical student notices that, unlike what he had seen with adult patients, no sterile precautions are taken prior to placing the catheter.  Aware of his status as the most junior member on the team, the student remains silent.  The following day, the patient becomes febrile and urine cultures grow Pseudomonas aeruginosa.  Which of the following would most likely have encouraged this student to express his concern to the team during the procedure?
questionList.explanationText:
Features of effective teams* in health care

Safety culture

  • Resource commitment to safety

Collaboration

  • Shared understanding & prioritization of goals
  • Distinct roles that avoid a steep hierarchy

Psychologic safety

  • Asking questions & voicing concerns encouraged
  • Avoiding blame or retaliation

Responsiveness

  • Feedback respected & promptly acted on

Situational awareness

  • Persistent mindfulness & safety vigilance
  • Cross-checking of each other's actions

Transparency

  • Prompt disclosure of errors & safety information

*Poor teamwork is a leading root cause of sentinel events; improved communication reduces medical errors & improves patient/clinical outcomes.

Effective teamwork allows each team member, regardless of status, to promote patient safety through vigilance (monitoring for error).  However, as this scenario illustrates, perception of steep hierarchy gradients increases fear of speaking up and medical error risk.  This student's hesitation to question the lack of sterile procedures prior to Foley catheter placement reflects low psychological safety (eg, comfort expressing safety-related concerns and questions without fear of intimidation), which is common with junior status on a team and inexperience with safety communication.

Team safety debriefings are collaborative discussions encouraging expression of safety-related concerns and actions in a specific situation.  They can occur before or after a clinical event.  Debriefings are used by high-reliability organizations (organizations with excellent safety records despite high risk, such as aviation) to strengthen safety culture (shared commitment to safety goals) and continuous team learning.  Attending team briefings can improve the student's psychological safety, confidence in safety culture, and familiarity with relevant communication skills, increasing likelihood of voicing his concerns during the procedure.

(Choice B)  Although rounding in interprofessional teams (eg, teams involving multiple disciplines, such as nursing, pharmacy, social work) can improve the student's communication and familiarity with health care fields, attending safety debriefings is a superior approach that addresses the student's status-based hesitation and specifically builds comfort with safety communication.

(Choice C)  Observing roles and communication driven by hierarchy, rather than mutual collaboration and merit, is likely to worsen fear linked to perceived lower status and reduce the student's psychological safety.  As seen in high-reliability organizations, team members should be encouraged to openly communicate concerns, regardless of hierarchical position, with team leaders valuing and equally respecting each member's input.

(Choice D)  Training in catheter placement techniques would improve the student's understanding of required sterile precautions in both pediatric and adult patients; however, it would not improve psychological safety or status-driven hesitation to speak up in a team setting.

Educational objective:
Psychological safety strengthens safety culture by enabling team members to express questions and concerns without fear and regardless of status.  Team-based safety briefings, used by high-reliability organizations (eg, aviation), improve communication skills and psychological safety by encouraging collaborative discussion and monitoring.
questionList.subject: Surgery
questionList.title: Patient safety

answerChoiceList.choice: Attendance at regular team safety debriefings
Experience rounding in interprofessional teams
Observation of hierarchy-based roles within teams
Training in catheter placement techniques

questionMappingReferencesList.title: A systematic review of factors enabling psychological safety in healthcare teams.

questionList.questionText: A 34-year-old man calls the office requesting an urgent appointment due to cough and cold symptoms.  His temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), but he feels "miserable" and is unsure if he should go to work the next day.  The patient has a history of seasonal allergies and knee pain from a past sports injury.  He has no other medical problems but does have a history of frequent office visits.  The receptionist informs him that the physician is preparing to leave as it is near closing time but that an appointment is available for the next morning.  The patient declines the offer of an appointment and hangs up.  As the physician leaves the office 30 minutes later to make evening rounds at the hospital, the patient arrives and insists on being seen immediately.  He sounds congested and coughs occasionally but is breathing normally.  He has no other symptoms.  He again asks to be examined.  Which of the following is the most appropriate response?
questionList.explanationText:
This physician is faced with a patient who inappropriately demands to be seen after hours for a non-urgent concern.  A stable patient who fails to arrive at the appointed time should be advised to reschedule the appointment; the physician is under no obligation to immediately see this patient.  Performing an examination after hours is inappropriate and reinforces the patient's sense of entitlement and poor boundaries.  Acquiescing to the patient's demands would only encourage similar behavior in the future and create further tension in the physician-patient relationship due to the patient's lack of respect for the physician's time (Choice F).

The most appropriate response is to calmly set limits and establish clear professional boundaries.  The physician should explain in a polite yet firm tone that the examination will be deferred until the next day because the condition is not an emergency.

(Choice B)  This response suggests that the patient's behavior is appropriate and offers an excuse not to see the patient rather than explaining that non-emergency concerns can wait.

(Choices C and E)  These responses set limits but are dismissive of the patient's concerns.  It is better to acknowledge the concerns but explain that non-urgent issues are addressed during regular office hours.

(Choice D)  Recommending that the patient go to the emergency department for a non-urgent condition is inappropriate and places an unnecessary burden on emergency services.

Educational objective:
Physicians should respond politely but firmly to inappropriate patient requests.  Maintaining professional boundaries is an important component of the physician-patient relationship.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Professional conduct

answerChoiceList.choice: "Although I understand your concern, we should address it tomorrow because it is not an emergency."
"I am sorry.  I would normally see you, but I have another appointment that can't wait."
"I am sorry you drove all this way, but your problem can wait until tomorrow."
"I insist that you go to the nearest emergency department for evaluation."
"I regret that I cannot see you now; didn't my staff inform you that it is closing time?"
"Let me take a quick look; it's probably nothing to worry about."

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Managing difficult encounters: understanding physician, patient, and situational factors.
