questionList.questionText: A multicenter randomized controlled trial is being conducted to assess the effectiveness of a treatment regimen involving peer group support and exercise for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).  The study intervention involves consultation with a physician, a registered dietitian, and a behavioral health specialist; participation in a structured exercise program; and attendance at weekly peer support groups.  Enrolled participants represent a diverse range of ages, symptom severity, and ethnicities; primary outcomes include patient-centered measures such as symptom severity and quality of life.  The investigators plan to compare this intervention to a control treatment.  Which of the following best describes an appropriate control treatment for this study?
questionList.explanationText:
Ethical considerations for randomized controlled trials

Appropriateness
of RCT

  • Intervention arms are at equipoise (ie, intervention is not already known to be superior to control)

Appropriateness
of control

  • Control is equivalent to the accepted standard of care
  • Control does not pose unacceptable risks to participant

Appropriateness
of inactive placebo

  • Acceptable when effective standard of care is unclear or does not exist

    OR

  • When effective standard of care exists, but temporarily withholding such therapy would not harm the participant

Appropriateness
of stopping RCT

  • Trial stopped when interim data analysis shows clear, highly significant benefit or harm

RCT = randomized controlled trial.

Selection of control interventions in randomized controlled trials (RCTs) should protect participant welfare.  In general, the control intervention should not already be established as clearly inferior to the active intervention (which would violate the ethical requirement of equipoise) and should follow current standards of care (eg, existing treatment guidelines), although placebo use is permissible in specific circumstances (eg, short-term trial in which withholding therapy would not harm participants).  The control treatment should also reduce bias by serving as a fair comparator to the intervention (eg, similar degree of appropriateness for symptom severity).

This RCT is studying a condition (ie, irritable bowel syndrome [IBS]) that is usually managed with multiple modalities (eg, medications, dietary guidance).  The study intervention, similarly, is a multicomponent process involving peer support, exercise, and multidisciplinary consultation, and is tested in diverse participants (eg, age, symptom severity, ethnicity).  Therefore, the most appropriate control intervention for this RCT is a multicomponent treatment regimen that reflects current IBS management guidelines.

(Choice A)  A medication is a less suitable control treatment for this study, which uses a multicomponent active intervention; a multicomponent control is preferred.  Moreover, medications showing benefits in preliminary studies are typically not suitable for use as a control because there is insufficient evidence regarding their effectiveness, optimal dosage, and safety.

(Choice B)  An inert medication (ie, placebo) is appropriate in limited circumstances (eg, effective treatment not available and/or minimal risk to participants from withholding treatment).  This trial is studying a multicomponent intervention for a complex disorder that, in many participants, is currently treatable using different modalities.  Therefore, a multicomponent control, rather than placebo, is preferred ethically; it also represents a more valid comparator to the active intervention.

(Choices C and E)  A control intervention that has been primarily studied only at an academic center or is used for a specialized subset of patients (eg, patients with refractory symptoms) would be less appropriate for this RCT which involves a general, diverse participant population.  Likewise, control interventions that are primarily intended for refractory cases may overtreat participants with mild symptoms and bias study results.

Educational objective:
Control interventions in randomized controlled trials should be selected to protect the welfare of research participants (eg, not withholding essential or curative treatments) while serving as a fair comparator to the intervention.  Control interventions should generally offer care that adheres to established treatment guidelines.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Research ethics

answerChoiceList.choice: A medication that was shown to benefit a subset of IBS symptoms in preliminary studies
A medication that was shown to have no benefit in IBS outcomes in preliminary studies
A multicomponent treatment that is commonly administered to patients with refractory IBS symptoms
A multicomponent treatment that reflects current IBS management guidelines
A multicomponent treatment that was recently developed and implemented at a major academic medical center

questionMappingReferencesList.title: A pragmatic view on pragmatic trials

questionList.questionText: The parents of a 16-year-old boy call the office to discuss concerns about their son's behavior.  The mother reports that he has been more distant, and his grades have declined over the past 2 months.  The patient has no significant medical history and takes no medication.  The parents ask if a urine drug test can be ordered without their son's knowledge.  The father says, "We just want to get him help if he needs it."  Which of the following is the most appropriate response to the parents?
questionList.explanationText:
Drug testing has many clinical uses; however, patients may consider it intrusive, and it risks false positive and false negative results.  In the case of adolescents, drug testing may also erode their trust of parents or caregivers.  Therefore, because of its limitations, drug testing should be considered only after a thorough history and physical examination suggest a clear indication and benefit.

In this scenario, parents have a concern that their son's declining grades and distant behavior are signs of substance use, but they have provided few details.  There are many possible explanations for this behavior change (eg, major depressive disorder, school bullying).  Therefore, the best approach is to obtain additional information about the parents' concerns and evaluate the adolescent for potential substance use or other mental health needs in privacy.  By pursuing a more comprehensive evaluation, the treatment plan can be appropriately tailored to address identified needs and avoid missing alternative explanations resulting from prematurely assuming drug use as the cause (Choice A).

In addition, adolescents should be involved in their own medical decision making, and parental concerns and the prospect of drug testing should be discussed with the adolescent.  Drug testing an unwilling adolescent patient is impractical, as the patient may refuse to share the results with parents.  Further, performing a drug test without the patient's knowledge is both unethical and illegal (Choice C).

(Choice D)  Surreptitious drug tests risk damaging the patient-physician relationship; however, the focus should be on further understanding the parent's concerns, not the physician's potential difficulties.

(Choice E)  Although this statement acknowledges the parents' desire to be helpful, it assigns blame for potential consequences of testing without first trying to better understand their fears or their rationale for requesting testing without the son's knowledge.

Educational objective:
Drug testing adolescents without their knowledge is inappropriate.  Parents requesting surreptitious drug testing should be engaged to understand their specific concerns, educated about the limitations of drug testing, and informed about the need for private patient evaluation.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Informed consent

answerChoiceList.choice: "Based on your son's behaviors, a drug screen is indicated; however, he must be informed of the testing and agree to it beforehand."
"Drug testing your son without his consent is not recommended; to better understand how he's doing, I'd like to hear about your concerns and evaluate him."
"Ordering a urine drug test for your son without his consent is an option, but I recommend that you try having a conversation with him about your concerns first."
"Trust between a physician and a patient is important; let me explain why this would put me in a very difficult position."
"You clearly want to help your son, but I'm concerned that you may be risking damage to your relationship by not being honest with him."

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Testing for drugs of abuse in children and adolescents.

questionList.questionText: A rural hospital launches a campaign to improve hand hygiene compliance among staff to reduce hospital-associated infections.  An educational presentation on hand hygiene protocols is held, and reminder signs are posted outside each patient room.  Each patient floor, which contains 16 rooms, is equipped with a handwashing station placed next to the nurses' station, consisting of an automatic soap dispenser, alcohol-based hand rub, sink, and boxes of gloves.  Additional sinks are located inside patient rooms.  Five weeks later, compliance with hand hygiene protocol is measured using infrared technology linked to identification badges to capture frequency of handwashing and by covert hand hygiene observers stationed on each floor.  The analysis reveals a current hand hygiene compliance rate of 40%.  Which intervention will likely promote the greatest improvement in hand hygiene compliance rates?
questionList.explanationText:
Improving hand hygiene compliance in health care settings

Reason for noncompliance

Example solution

Ineffective placement
of sinks & dispensers

Place sinks/dispensers outside each patient's room

Lack of accountability

Build hand hygiene into provider evaluations

Lack of safety culture

Create safety teams, provide real-time feedback on compliance

Forgetfulness or lack of time

Place visual cues (eg, signs, red arrows) near doorways

Optimal hand hygiene (cleansing and disinfecting hands with soap or antiseptic hand rub) can reduce incidence of preventable, hospital-associated infections (HAI) by up to 70%.  However, compliance rates in most health care settings are typically low (20%-50%), due to inconvenience and insufficient number of handwashing stations.  This hospital has only one external handwashing station per floor, requiring providers to walk to the nurses' station to cleanse hands when outside patient rooms.  Installing additional handwashing stations outside of each patient room increases provider access to sanitizer and the likelihood of proper cleansing of hands before and after seeing a patient.  This intervention demonstrates environmental reengineering, a systems approach most likely to improve provider behavior.

According to the CDC, the preferred hand hygiene method in most clinical settings is antiseptic hand rub (eg, alcohol-based disinfectant).  All hand surfaces should be covered and rubbed until dry (~20 sec).  However, if hands are visibly soiled or exposure to spores (eg, infectious diarrhea, Clostridioides [formerly Clostridium] difficile infection) is suspected, hands should be washed thoroughly with soap and water (~20 sec).

(Choices A and D)  Although handouts and didactic sessions can address provider knowledge deficiency, an educational session has already occurred in this hospital, and didactic approaches are less effective than environmental reengineering in promoting behavior change.  Furthermore, handouts should ideally be placed at point-of-care locations (eg, by patient doors), rather than physically handed to providers, to serve as a visual cue prompting compliance.

(Choice C)  Placing gloves outside patient rooms is unlikely to increase hand hygiene compliance because it does not increase provider access to sinks and sanitizing stations.  Although gloves are part of universal precautions and should be worn prior to possible contact with bodily fluids, hand hygiene is still required before putting on and after removing gloves, or when damage or visible soiling is seen.

(Choice E)  Waiting an additional 3 weeks and remeasuring compliance without any environmental or systems changes is unlikely to meaningfully improve provider behaviors.

Educational objective:
Following hand hygiene recommendations (eg, cleansing hands using antiseptic hand rub or soap and water) can substantially reduce health care–associated infections, but provider compliance in health care settings is typically low.  Physical environmental reengineering (eg, improving number and placement of hand hygiene stations) is a systems approach that increases provider likelihood of hand hygiene compliance.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Patient safety

answerChoiceList.choice: Distributing handouts to all staff emphasizing the importance of hand hygiene
Installing alcohol-based disinfectant stations outside each patient room
Placing brightly colored boxes of gloves outside patient rooms
Requiring staff to attend additional didactic training sessions
Waiting an additional 3 weeks and remeasuring compliance

questionMappingReferencesList.title: How "user friendly" is the hospital for practicing hand hygiene? an ergonomic evaluation.

questionList.questionText: A double-blinded, randomized controlled trial is being conducted to assess whether a new chemotherapeutic agent can prolong survival in patients with stage III non–small cell lung cancer.  Recent research studies using a small group of subjects reported that the agent demonstrated the ability to reduce tumor burden.  Investigators conducting the current trial now plan to randomly assign a larger number of participants to receive either the experimental treatment or a control intervention and measure differences in survival between the 2 groups.  Which of the following characteristics should be present within the research trial to ensure adequate protection of participants' welfare?
questionList.explanationText:
Ethical considerations for randomized controlled trials

Appropriateness
of RCT

  • Intervention arms are at equipoise (ie, intervention is not already known to be superior to control)

Appropriateness
of control

  • Control is equivalent to the accepted standard of care
  • Control does not pose unacceptable risks to participant

Appropriateness
of inactive placebo

  • Acceptable when effective standard of care is unclear or does not exist

    OR

  • When effective standard of care exists, but temporarily withholding such therapy would not harm the participant

Appropriateness
of stopping RCT

  • Trial stopped when interim data analysis shows clear, highly significant benefit or harm

RCT = randomized controlled trial.

Randomized controlled trials (RCTs) are regarded as the most statistically unbiased method for determining whether an intervention (eg, new chemotherapeutic agent) causes an outcome (eg, increased survival).  However, RCTs pose ethical risks because participants lack autonomy in choosing their treatment and are randomly allocated to an intervention that may, depending on the study's results, be found to be inferior (eg, control or experimental arm).

Randomization of participants within an RCT is ethically permissible only if there is general uncertainty (ie, clinical equipoise) regarding the effectiveness of the experimental compared to the control intervention.  Equipoise is necessary in study design to ensure that the trial does not knowingly randomize participants at the outset to a clearly inferior or superior arm (Choice C).  For this reason, RCTs typically test interventions that are hypothesized to have benefit based on lower-quality evidence (eg, small pilot study) but lack robust evidence or widespread scientific consensus for their effectiveness.  Determining effectiveness then represents the primary purpose of the RCT.

(Choice A)  For RCTs to maintain statistical integrity, disease severity and other participant characteristics must be similarly distributed between the control and experimental groups.  Preferential allocation of subjects to a specific group violates the goals of randomization and would compromise the results of the study.

(Choice B)  In general, control treatments should reflect current standards of care (eg, standard chemotherapy regimen for lung cancer).  An inactive placebo (or intervention known to be less effective) is appropriate only when no effective treatment exists or when temporarily withholding treatment would not result in significant harm to participants.  Given the rapidly progressive nature of stage III non–small cell lung cancer, it is inappropriate to choose a control intervention that is less effective than the current standard of care (such as a placebo).

Educational objective:
In a randomized controlled trial, randomization is ethically permissible only if there is uncertainty (equipoise) regarding the comparative effectiveness of the experimental and control interventions.  Typically, control interventions for treatable, progressive diseases should reflect usual standards of care and not be known to be inferior to the experimental intervention.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Research ethics

answerChoiceList.choice: Preferential allocation of participants with greater symptom severity to the experimental arm
Selection of a control treatment that is less effective compared to the current standard of care
Selection of a control treatment that is less effective compared to the intervention
Uncertainty regarding the intervention's effectiveness compared to the control treatment

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Review of clinical equipoise: examples from oncology trials.
Equipoise and the RCT.

questionList.questionText: A 52-year-old man undergoes emergency laparotomy for peritonitis after he was stabbed in the abdomen during a robbery.  During the operation, minor spillage of enteric contents is discovered, and a small bowel injury is found and repaired.  When the rest of the intraabdominal organs are examined for injury, an approximately 10 cm gastric mass is found that appears most consistent with a gastrointestinal stromal tumor.  Resection of the mass would require partial gastrectomy.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questionList.explanationText:
Informed consent is the process by which a physician provides a patient with the information necessary to make an educated health care decision.  Informed consent is typically required prior to performing a procedure on a patient, although important exceptions exist:

  • A life-saving procedure may be performed in an emergency where obtaining consent is not possible.
  • Extension of a procedure is acceptable if an unexpected complication arises that requires immediate treatment (eg, unexpected ostomy creation is necessary because profound enteric spillage makes bowel repair unsafe).  The additional procedure is typically related to the initial indication (eg, peritonitis) for treatment.

This patient is undergoing emergency laparotomy because of peritonitis after penetrating trauma. Following appropriate treatment (ie, repair of injured small bowel), a large gastric mass is incidentally discovered.  In this case, the mass's removal is not related to the original indication for surgery, its presence is not imminently life-threatening, and its resection would cause additional risks to the patient.  Therefore, the mass should not be removed without the patient's further consent.

Advantages of deferring resection of the gastric mass include avoiding the increased risk of infection (eg, from enteric spillage) and limiting operative time in the setting of trauma (Choices A and C).  Advantages to performing a simultaneous resection include avoiding another operation in the setting of adhesions and decreasing total medical costs and patient recovery time (Choices E and F).  However, none of these advantages (for either deferred or simultaneous resection) override the necessity of obtaining the patient's informed consent before performing the additional procedure.

(Choice D)  A gastric mass of this size (ie, 10 cm) has a high likelihood of malignancy, and resection is likely to be recommended after complete workup (eg, imaging to rule out lymph node involvement or metastases).  However, it is the patient's (not the surgeon's) right to choose (or refuse) resection, even if the mass is malignant.

Educational objective:
An exception to the requirement of informed consent is extension of an authorized procedure if an unexpected complication arises that demands immediate treatment.  However, this exception does not cover procedures for unrelated issues that are not imminently life-threatening.
questionList.subject: Surgery
questionList.title: Informed consent

answerChoiceList.choice: Do not resect the mass because of the increased risk of infection
Do not resect the mass because of the lack of patient consent
Do not resect the mass to limit operative time in the setting of trauma
Resect the mass because of the high likelihood of malignancy
Resect the mass to avoid another operation in the setting of abdominal adhesions
Resect the mass to decrease total medical costs and recovery time for the patient

questionMappingReferencesList.title: From informed consent to informed dissent in health care: historical evolution in the twentieth century.
Informed consentit's more than a signature on a piece of paper.

questionList.questionText: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the office by her mother for a routine health maintenance evaluation.  The patient attends middle school and does well academically and socially.  She has no significant medical history.  The patient is tracking along the growth curve at the 50th percentile, is up to date on all vaccinations, and has not yet experienced menarche.  Physical examination shows Tanner stage II breast development and pubic hair consistent with Tanner stage I.  After the examination, the patient's mother says, "My daughter is doing really well.  However, I was diagnosed with early-stage BRCA1-positive breast cancer, and my mother died at the age of 55 from breast cancer.  I noticed my daughter is starting to develop breasts, and I am concerned that she is at risk.  Should I have her tested now?"  Which of the following is the best response to this patient's mother?
questionList.explanationText:
Genetic testing for identification of a pathogenic (disease-causing) genetic variant is common.  However, there are psychosocial and ethical issues to consider when performing genetic testing in children.  Above all, the decision to perform testing should consider the child's best interests.

Testing in children is typically performed based on the onset of disease.  Tests for genetic conditions with an early onset of disease (eg, cystic fibrosis, phenylketonuria) are performed because early diagnosis affects management in childhood.  In contrast, genetic testing in children for an adult-onset condition (eg, breast cancer) is typically not recommended because it usually does not affect patient care (eg, frequency of monitoring) or prognosis (Choice C).  In addition, genetic testing has complex risks, benefits, and ramifications, and children lack the legal capacity and often the cognitive and psychosocial maturity to provide informed consent.

This mother is understandably concerned about her daughter's breast cancer risk.  Because BRCA1/2 inheritance is autosomal dominant, first- and second-degree relatives (eg, this daughter) of an affected individual (ie, this mother) are candidates for genetic testing.  However, testing the daughter at this time will not affect management but could have adverse psychosocial effects depending on negative or positive results (eg, survivor guilt, prolonged anxiety).  Therefore, testing should be deferred until adulthood, when the patient is old enough to understand and evaluate the risks and benefits for herself.

(Choices A and B)  Breast cancer monitoring during childhood has no benefit but has potential psychosocial harm.  Unlike tests used for screening (eg, colonoscopy for colon cancer), the timing of predictive genetic testing for BRCA1/2 does not depend on the affected relative's age at diagnosis.  If a pathogenic BRCA1/2 variation is confirmed, patients typically undergo breast cancer screening (eg, MRI) beginning at age 25.  Risk-reducing surgery for breast and ovarian cancer (ie, prophylactic mastectomy and salpingo-oophorectomy) is also discussed with adult carriers.

Educational objective:
Genetic testing in children should consider the best interests of the child.  When there is no impact on the child's medical management or prognosis, genetic testing to predict future disease risk should be deferred until adulthood to ensure informed consent.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Genetic testing

answerChoiceList.choice: "I recommend BRCA testing 5 years prior to the age when you were diagnosed with breast cancer."
"I recommend close monitoring and BRCA testing only if signs or symptoms of breast cancer develop."
"I recommend testing as soon as possible to guide the frequency of monitoring and follow-up."
"I recommend waiting until the child is old enough to understand the risks and benefits of testing."

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Points to consider: ethical, legal, and psychosocial implications of genetic testing in children and adolescents.
Ethical and policy issues in genetic testing and screening of children.

questionList.questionText: A 28-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain.  The patient reports a constant, dull pain in her lower abdomen that is accompanied by nausea at times.  She has no vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, or appetite changes.  The patient was evaluated for similar symptoms at an urgent care clinic a month ago and at the emergency department last week; at that time, pelvic examination, laboratory evaluation, and CT scan of the abdomen revealed no abnormalities.  The patient is sexually active with her boyfriend and moved in with him a few months ago.  She has no chronic medical conditions and takes no medications.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6), blood pressure is 118/74, and pulse is 80/min.  Heart and lung sounds are normal.  Abdominal examination shows no tenderness to palpation, rebound, or guarding.  The remainder of the physical examination is normal.  Which of the following statements is most appropriate at this time?
questionList.explanationText:
Assessment of intimate partner violence

Signs

  • Location of injuries (eg, genitals, torso, face, head, neck)
  • Inconsistent explanation, evasive, fearful
  • Nonadherence to follow-up, emergency department visits
  • Partner who resists patient being seen alone
  • Discomfort in examination, sexually transmitted infections, chronic pelvic pain

Interview strategies

  • Ensure privacy
  • Nonjudgmental, empathic, open-ended questions
  • Avoid pressuring to disclose abuse or report or leave partner
  • Assess immediate safety; determine emergency safety plan, provide referrals for resources as needed (eg, shelters, domestic violence agency, mental health)

This patient with chronic lower abdominal pain and several normal evaluations requires screening for intimate partner violence (IPV).  IPV is any type of harm (ie, physical, psychological, sexual) committed by a partner.  IPV particularly affects women of childbearing age, with increased incidence during times of stress or social changes (eg, marriage, postpartum, moving in with partner).  However, IPV is often underreported by patients due to shame, self-blame, or fear of retribution.

Therefore, a high degree of clinical suspicion for IPV must be maintained.  When somatic symptoms do occur, they are often nonspecific (eg, headaches, back pain, chronic abdominal or pelvic pain).  Additional clues may be present, such as resistance to being evaluated alone and multiple medical visits with varying health care providers (eg, emergency visits).  Physical examination findings may include unexplained bruising on the head, neck, abdomen, or genitals; however, patients can have a normal examination.

Patients with suspected IPV should undergo screening.  Because this is a sensitive topic, providers should begin with a normalizing statement (eg, "I sometimes see patients with similar pain that is caused by not feeling safe") and proceed with both open-ended (eg, "How safe do you feel in your relationship?") and specific (eg, "Have you ever been hit by your partner?") questions to encourage disclosure.

(Choice A)  Regular visits with the same provider (eg, primary care) and avoidance of unnecessary specialist referrals may be indicated for somatic symptom disorder, which is the excessive preoccupation or anxiety with ≥1 somatic symptom.  In this patient, further psychosocial evaluation is required for this diagnosis.

(Choice B)  This close-ended statement does not address potential psychosocial causes of pain (eg, IPV, mood disorders) and may discourage the patient from disclosure.

(Choice D)  Although this response is empathetic, recommendations for symptom control are inappropriate until the underlying etiology of this patient's abdominal pain is understood.

Educational objective:
Intimate partner violence can present with chronic, nonspecific somatic symptoms (eg, headaches, abdominal pain) and a normal physical evaluation.  Evaluation for contributing psychosocial factors and a high degree of clinical suspicion is required.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Intimate partner violence

answerChoiceList.choice: "All of your testing has been normal so far; I recommend following up with your primary care doctor so your symptoms can be further evaluated."
"Based on your examination today and your prior evaluations, there does not appear to be a physical basis to your symptoms."
"I sometimes see patients with similar pain that is caused by feeling unsafe in their relationships; is this happening to you?"
"Many patients experience improvement in their pain symptoms with low-intensity exercises; can I share some resources that may be helpful?"

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Managing intimate partner violence in the emergency department.
Intimate partner violence.

questionList.questionText:
The following vignette applies to the next 2 items.  The items in the set must be answered in sequential order.  Once you click Proceed to Next Item, you will not be able to add or change an answer.

Item 1 of 2

Administrators at a tertiary care hospital conduct a survey of multiple categories of operating room personnel, including surgeons, anesthesiologists, and nurses, who perform complex orthopedic procedures (eg, hip arthroscopy).  The survey asks respondents to score perceived quality of collaboration and communication with each category of team members on a scale of 1–100.  A matrix depicting peer-peer scores is presented below:

Personnel
performing
rating		Personnel being rated
SurgeonAnesthesiologistNurse
Surgeon908588
Anesthesiologist709689
Nurse486381

Which of the following is the most likely underlying factor leading to these results?
questionList.explanationText:
Teamwork is necessary for patient safety in complex, high-risk environments (eg, operating room).  Teams in the operating room are often interprofessional (involving members from different professions, such as physicians and nurses).  High-functioning teams are characterized by collaboration and a shared understanding of team goals and functions.  This survey's results illustrate suboptimal interprofessional collaboration:

  • Perceived collaboration across personnel types (eg, nurse-anesthesiologist, anesthesiologist-surgeon) is consistently worse than perceived collaboration within personnel types (eg, nurse-nurse, surgeon-surgeon)

  • Nurses perceive the lowest quality collaboration with other personnel categories (eg, nurse-anesthesiologist score of 63; nurse-surgeon score of 48)

  • Pronounced differences in perceived collaboration exists between nurses and surgeons (eg, surgeon-nurse score of 88 compared to nurse-surgeon score of 48)

Suboptimal interprofessional collaboration is most often due to differences in understanding of team goals, including perceptions of each team member's specific role and opinions on how the team should function.  For example, evidence indicates team leaders (eg, surgeons) are more likely to define team collaboration as prompt and accurate adherence to instructions, whereas other members (eg, nurses) are more likely to define collaboration as feeling that their input is respected and acknowledged.  Excessive team hierarchy can prevent team members from voicing their opinions and perceptions, compromising patient safety.

(Choice A)  Cognitive bias refers to unconscious mental shortcuts that influence individual decision-making (eg, formation of differential diagnosis, choice of diagnostic tests).  It is less of a factor in teamwork, which relies on group communication and collaboration.

(Choice C)  Variations in technical expertise and medical knowledge are common in interprofessional teams but should not undermine team performance if each member is well integrated into the team structure.  Teams can achieve optimal collaboration by promoting a consistent, shared understanding of team goals and functions.

(Choice D)  Although fatigue and sleep deprivation can affect job performance, nurses on this team express a high perceived quality of collaboration with other nurses, suggesting that the primary difference in ratings is due to different definitions of teamwork and collaboration rather than fatigue among nurses.

Educational objective:
High-functioning teams are characterized by collaboration, which requires a shared understanding of team goals and functions of each team member.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Patient safety

answerChoiceList.choice: Cognitive bias among nurses and surgeons
Differences in understanding of team goals
Differences in medical knowledge and technical skills
Fatigue and sleep deprivation among nurses

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Differences in nurse and surgeon perceptions of teamwork: implications for use of a briefing checklist in the OR.
Perceptions of teamwork in the OR: roles and expectations.
Safety culture in the operating room: variability among perioperative healthcare workers.

questionList.questionText:
Item 2 of 2

Hospital administrators are interested in developing initiatives to improve communication and collaboration within the operative team.  Which of the following interventions is most likely to address the findings revealed by the survey?
questionList.explanationText:
Features of effective teams* in health care

Safety culture

  • Resource commitment to safety

Collaboration

  • Shared understanding & prioritization of goals
  • Distinct roles that avoid a steep hierarchy

Psychologic safety

  • Asking questions & voicing concerns encouraged
  • Avoiding blame or retaliation

Responsiveness

  • Feedback respected & promptly acted on

Situational awareness

  • Persistent mindfulness & safety vigilance
  • Cross-checking of each other's actions

Transparency

  • Prompt disclosure of errors & safety information

*Poor teamwork is a leading root cause of sentinel events; improved communication reduces medical errors & improves patient/clinical outcomes.

The survey results indicate that the perceived quality of collaboration is suboptimal among members of the  operative team.  Team debriefings are brief, interprofessional structured discussions held before or after a clinical event (eg, before an operation, following a safety incident).  Evidence from high-reliability organizations (high-risk industries with excellent safety records) illustrates that debriefings optimize interprofessional collaboration by improving the following components of team functioning:

  • Shared understanding:  Reinforce the team's primary goals and each member's specific role on the team

  • Psychological safety:  Encourage each team member to voice concerns (eg, potential factors increasing risk for errors) in a group setting with feedback and acknowledgment

  • Reduce hierarchy:  Value every team member's role in achieving goals and promoting safety

  • Coordination:  Establish action items to address concerns and ensure accurate understanding

Debriefings are typically led by two individuals on the team.  Engaging nurses (who perceive the lowest quality of interprofessional team collaboration) as co-leaders in the debriefings provides a way for nurses to express input, engage, and share feedback with the team; this is most likely to help reduce hierarchy (eg, with surgeon) and improve interprofessional collaboration.

(Choice A)  Lean methods are quality improvement processes that are primarily oriented toward improving efficiency and reducing waste (eg, extended wait times in a clinic), rather than team communication.

(Choices C and D)  Although checklists and templates are recommended for safety purposes, they are less effective in improving interprofessional collaboration.  Debriefings are a superior tool for improving hierarchical barriers, psychological safety, and collaboration.  Moreover, a solution involving only handoffs and transfers does not address team dynamics during procedures.

(Choice E)  Although training in principles of safety vigilance can improve communication, interventions to address poor teamwork should involve interactions within a team (eg, team debriefing), rather than surgeons alone.

Educational objective:
Team debriefings are interprofessional, structured discussions that can be held before or after a clinical event (eg, prior to an operation, after a safety incident) and can improve team collaboration and achievement of shared team goals.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Patient safety

answerChoiceList.choice: Having anesthesiologists lead teams in Lean methods for quality improvement
Having nurses lead portions of the perioperative team safety briefings and debriefings
Training nurses and surgeons in use of checklists during high-risk procedures
Training surgeons and nurses to use a template during handoffs and transfers
Training surgeons in principles of safety vigilance and monitoring

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Effects of perioperative briefing and debriefing on patient safety: a prospective intervention study.

questionList.questionText: A 53-year-old man comes to the emergency department of an academic medical center with back pain after lifting a heavy box a day earlier.  The patient appears anxious and in pain.  He says, "I'm worried I've twisted a nerve in my back, and I really hope you are going to do an MRI."  A second-year resident obtains the patient's history and conducts an initial physical examination.  Palpation of the lower back reveals paravertebral tenderness on the left side at the L4 level; there is no tenderness to palpation over the spine.  Strength and sensation in both extremities are intact, and deep tendon reflexes are symmetric.  The resident presents his findings to the attending physician, mentioning the patient's concerns and request for MRI.  As the attending physician examines the patient, which of the following statements is most recommended to reduce patient requests for unnecessary imaging?
questionList.explanationText:
Resource overuse (eg, unnecessary imaging for uncomplicated low back pain) is associated with increased health care costs and suboptimal patient outcomes.  Current guidelines specify that imaging is not indicated for uncomplicated, acute back pain (<4-6 weeks) lacking "red flags" (eg, constitutional symptoms, prior malignancy).  However, patient concerns about serious but unlikely causes of pain (eg, significant nerve injury) may precipitate expectations for imaging that conflict with optimal care and physician judgment.

Patients with low back pain are less likely to request imaging studies when they believe the physician has performed a thorough physical examination that checks for serious pathology and they receive a specific explanation of their condition.  Recommended practices include the following:

  • Apply patient-centered (rather than paternalistic) approaches to build a patient-physician partnership and directly address patient concerns.

  • Perform a detailed physical examination, giving special attention to areas that are concerning to the patient and providing ongoing commentary on what structures are being assessed and the significance of findings.

This patient's request for imaging is likely linked to his concern for nerve damage; providing specific commentary during the examination confirming that his nerve function is normal is likely to reassure the patient and support subsequent discussions explaining why imaging is unnecessary.

(Choice B)  This statement simply reiterates the physician's perspective regarding imaging but does not address the concerns that precipitated the patient's imaging request.

(Choice C)  This statement is vague (eg, physical examination is "normal"), does not address the patient's specific concerns, and is less likely to reassure the patient.

(Choice D)  This statement is physician- rather than patient-centered, does not address the patient's specific concern, and is likely to be perceived as dismissive.

(Choice E)  This statement describes a potential cause of the pain; however, it does not reassure the patient that the physician has assessed for nerve damage and is likely to be less effective than specifically addressing nerve function.

Educational objective:
Patients with low back pain are less likely to request unnecessary imaging studies when they believe the physician has thoroughly checked for serious pathology and has addressed their specific concerns (eg, nerve damage).  The physician should perform a detailed physical examination with specific, ongoing commentary on the structures being assessed and the significance of findings.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Overutilization of resources

answerChoiceList.choice: "I will now test your nerves and spinal cord, to confirm both are functioning normally."
"MRI can be very expensive and is unnecessary for you; it is better to try exercise and physical therapy instead."
"Since the findings from the resident physician's examination are normal, MRI is not likely to show anything meaningful."
"We see patients with this condition all the time, and it will get better in a few days."
"Your pain appears to be caused by tight back muscles and can be treated with muscle relaxants."

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Diagnostic imaging for low back pain: advice for high-value health care from the American College of Physicians.

questionList.questionText: A 29-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to acute lightheadedness.  The patient was seen by her family physician for viral gastroenteritis 2 days earlier and was prescribed ondansetron; she has taken the medication twice daily since then with significant reduction in vomiting.  Medical and family history are unremarkable.  The patient takes no other medications.  While in the emergency department, she develops ventricular fibrillation and becomes unconscious, requiring cardiopulmonary resuscitation and defibrillation.  The patient regains consciousness with normal sinus rhythm and is transferred to the intensive care unit, where she has no further arrhythmias.  After consultation with the cardiologist, it is believed that ondansetron may have triggered the patient's arrhythmia, an adverse effect that occurs in an average of 2 out of 10,000 patients.  Which of the following best describes the family physician's medical liability related to this adverse event?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient experienced a relatively rare (eg, 2 in 10,000) adverse drug event (eg, cardiac arrhythmia) due to ondansetron, a medication commonly prescribed for nausea and vomiting.  To determine whether medical malpractice occurred, all the following must be present:

  • The physician has a duty to care for the patient (ie, a patient-physician relationship has been formally established).

  • The physician's action deviated from standards of care, typically determined by current clinical guidelines.

  • The deviation from standards of care directly caused damages to the patient, which may include physical injury, emotional suffering, and loss of wages.  Damages need not be irreversible for malpractice to occur (Choice D).

This physician had a duty to care for the patient, and the physician's prescription of ondansetron likely directly caused this patient's arrhythmia.  However, the patient had no known risk factors for arrhythmia that would be reasonably detected under current standard screening procedures (eg, the patient has no personal or family history of cardiac arrhythmias and does not take other proarrhythmic medications [eg, antipsychotics]).  Therefore, the physician's prescription adheres to standards of care and does not constitute malpractice (Choice C).

In contrast, screening all patients with ECGs prior to prescribing ondansetron is impractical (eg, time, cost) and does not reflect current standard practice (Choice B).  Moreover, although physicians have a duty to ensure patients understand risks and benefits of using specific medications, including common adverse effects, they are not required to discuss all rare adverse effects listed on the package insert (Choice A).

Educational objective:
To constitute medical malpractice, the physician's actions must have deviated from standards of care, and that deviation must have caused damages to the patient (eg, psychological, bodily injury, lost wages).
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Physician misconduct

answerChoiceList.choice: Malpractice is evident because the physician failed to advise the patient of the risk of arrhythmia
Malpractice is evident because the physician failed to obtain an ECG before prescribing ondansetron
Malpractice is evident because the physician's treatment decision directly caused patient's harm
Malpractice is not evident because the patient did not suffer irreversible harm
Malpractice is not evident because the physician's management followed standards of care

questionList.questionText: A 58-year-old man with a history of well-controlled hypertension comes to the office due to low back pain for the past 5 days.  He first noticed the pain when bending over to lift a package at home.  The pain radiates down into his right leg with mild weakness.  He has no numbness or bowel or bladder incontinence.  He has been taking acetaminophen and ibuprofen as needed for the pain.  He works as an accountant at a large corporation.  Temperature is 36.7 C (98 F), blood pressure is 123/87 mm Hg, and pulse is 75/min.  Neurologic examination shows 5/5 strength in the left lower extremity and 4/5 strength in the right lower extremity; reflexes are 2+ throughout.  Straight-leg raise test is positive on the right.  The physician diagnoses the patient with sciatica and recommends physical therapy and strengthening exercises.  The patient states that he is unable to sit for more than 2 hours without feeling the pain in his leg and that it is interfering with his job.  He says, "I just don't see how I can work right now.  Can you help me qualify for social security disability benefits?"  What is the most appropriate next action by the physician?
questionList.explanationText:
Disability insurance

Definition

  • Financial assistance for employees unable to perform full job duties due to illness
  • May be short term (eg, <6 weeks) or long term
  • Offered through private insurance or Social Security Administration

Clinician's role

  • Document findings related to medical condition
  • Define severity & expected duration of condition
  • Identify restrictions & job-related functional limitations

Challenges

  • Disability definitions & certification requirements vary by program
  • Determining disability duration may require longitudinal & repeated evaluation
  • Clinician assessment may conflict with patient preferences

Disability insurance provides employees with financial assistance if they experience a medical condition impairing their ability to work.  Short-term disability (<6 weeks) is typically offered through private insurance programs, whereas long-term benefits may be funded privately or through the federal Social Security Administration.  Disability benefits are often contingent upon physician certification of the patient's impairment, including severity, limitation of job-related functions (eg, standing, lifting), and expected duration (eg, temporary, permanent).

This patient has sciatica causing functional impairment (ie, unable to sit for >2 hours).  However, he has only had 5 days of symptoms, and his duration of impairment is uncertain.  Moreover, it is possible that workplace modifications (eg, changing computer positioning, periodic breaks) may enable him to fulfill job obligations without extended time off.  Therefore, it is inappropriate to certify this patient now for long-term disability benefits (Choice A).  Instead, the physician can certify the patient for limited time off (eg, 3-5 days of medical leave), and subsequently reassess the patient.

(Choice B)  Musculoskeletal imaging can sometimes support certification for long-term disability but is not required or sufficient because structural findings on imaging may not correlate with the severity of functional impairment.  Moreover, imaging is not currently indicated in this patient, who has minimal weakness and no red flags (eg, bowel or bladder incontinence).

(Choice D)  Visit summaries, which contain detailed patient information belonging to the patient's medical record, are not generally intended to be reviewed by employers.  When a patient requires extended medical leave (eg, through the Family Medical Leave Act), the physician's disclosure of pertinent health information (with patient consent) is typically limited to information requested (eg, date of disability onset, nature of limitations) on a standard, employer-generated form.

(Choice E)  Specialist assessment can provide useful information regarding treatment and long-term prognosis if the patient's condition does not resolve but is premature at this stage because the patient's symptoms may resolve spontaneously.

Educational objective:
Disability benefits, which compensate employees unable to fulfill job duties due to medical conditions, can be short term (<6 weeks) or long term (eg, through the Social Security Administration).  Determination of disability in patients with potentially temporary conditions requires ongoing assessment and follow-up; in the acute phase, physicians can certify such patients for limited time off work (eg, 3-5 days).
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Disability

answerChoiceList.choice: Certify the patient for disability benefits based on his diagnosis
Certify the patient for disability benefits only if musculoskeletal imaging confirms structural disease
Decline the patient's request but offer to certify him for limited time off work
Provide the patient with a visit summary including diagnosis to be given to his employer
Refer the patient to a physical medicine and rehabilitation specialist for disability evaluation

questionList.questionText: A 44-year-old psychology professor with a history of chronic rheumatoid arthritis comes to the office for a follow-up examination.  She is currently taking prednisone and infliximab, a regimen that has successfully stabilized her condition.  She enjoys swimming 3 or 4 times a week, which helps with her strength and keeps her weight on target.  Temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse is 78/min, and respirations are 16/min.  The patient weighs 65 kg (143.3 lb) and is 162.5 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall.  Physical examination reveals no significant changes.  Toward the end of the visit, the patient mentions that a family friend who suffers with chronic pain secondary to a spinal fusion has had a good response to acupuncture.  She would like to try acupuncture instead of the medications she is taking currently.  Which of the following is the most appropriate response to this patient's request?
questionList.explanationText:
Patients are increasingly interested in complementary and alternative medicine (CAM), and physicians must be prepared to discuss CAM modalities with them and integrate treatments that have demonstrated safety and efficacy.  The initial response to a patient who requests an alternative approach is to explore the reasons for requesting a different treatment.

This patient may be dissatisfied or have concerns about the quality of current care.  She may be experiencing bothersome medication side effects of which the physician is unaware.  Once the patient's reasons are clarified, the physician can discuss the risks and benefits of the proposed CAM treatment in addition to suggesting modifications to the current treatment regimen that may address her concerns.

(Choice A)  This response enthusiastically endorses the patient's request for acupuncture without first understanding what is prompting her request.  In addition, it makes a general statement about the benefits of CAM that is inaccurate in her case given the lack of evidence for acupuncture in rheumatoid arthritis and the risks of discontinuing the current treatments.

(Choice B)  Although studies have not demonstrated acupuncture's efficacy for rheumatoid arthritis, this response rejects the patient's suggestion outright without first exploring the reasons for her request.  The risks and benefits of the proposed treatment can be discussed after the physician has gained a better understanding of the patient's perspective.

(Choice C)  Warning the patient about the risks of stopping her current treatment regimen is dismissive of her request and likely to damage the physician-patient relationship.  The first step is to understand why she is requesting a change in her treatment.  The risks of stopping her current medications can be addressed at a later point.

(Choice D)  It would be premature to refer the patient for acupuncture without first understanding the reasons behind her request.

Educational objective:
The initial response to patients suggesting complementary and alternative medicine is to explore their reasons for requesting such treatment.  Physicians must be prepared to discuss the risks and benefits of complementary and alternative approaches to treatment and be open to integrating modalities with proven safety and efficacy.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Complementary and alternative medicine

answerChoiceList.choice: Acupuncture is definitely something we can try; alternative treatments can be very beneficial.
Acupuncture should not be used as it has not demonstrated efficacy for rheumatoid arthritis.
I am concerned that your condition will worsen rapidly if you stop your medications.
I am not familiar with acupuncture but can refer you to a clinician experienced in the procedure.
Tell me more about your interest in trying acupuncture for your condition.

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Integrative medicine and patient-centered care.
A qualitative systematic review of patients' experiences of acupuncture.
Integration of acupuncture into conventional medicine from health professionals' perspective: a thematic synthesis of qualitative studies.

questionList.questionText: A 42-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of weight management.  The patient notes that she has not been able to lose any weight despite making dietary changes and exercising 3 times a week for the past 6 months.  She is planning to start taking ephedra, an herbal supplement containing ephedrine, that she purchased online to assist with weight loss.  The risks of ephedra are discussed, and the patient is advised not to take the supplement.  Prescription weight loss medications are reviewed, but the patient declines, stating that she would like to first try ephedra because many of her friends have had sustained weight loss with the supplement.  Medical history is otherwise noncontributory.  Vital signs are normal.  BMI is 36 kg/m2.  Physical examination shows obese habitus but is otherwise normal.  Which of the following is the most appropriate statement?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient is planning to take a weight loss supplement (ie, ephedra) that can cause significant cardiovascular toxicity (eg, hypertension, stroke).  Dietary supplements containing ephedrine are banned in the United States, although patients are occasionally able to obtain them from international and online sources.  In addition to toxicity concerns, such nonstandard medications are often produced under unstandardized manufacturing practices, which may be associated with significant variation in the quantity and purity of the active ingredient and possible adulteration.

When discussing a patient's use of nonstandard therapies that are known to be harmful, the physician should clearly explain the risks to the patient.  However, despite the risks, some patients are insistent to proceed with such treatments, often based on anecdotal reports or testimonials.

In such cases, the physician should respect patient autonomy, understanding and acknowledging the patient's motivations for taking the therapy.  The physician should continue to be involved in the patient's care to monitor for toxicity (eg, elevated blood pressure) and develop a stronger therapeutic alliance (Choice A).  Frequent follow-up is often helpful, and in time, the patient may come to better trust the physician's advice and discontinue the harmful therapy.

(Choices B and E)  Offering standard obesity treatment or consulting a specialist provider may eventually lead to use of safer, more appropriate therapies.  However, this patient has already stated a commitment to using a potentially harmful treatment, and close follow-up should be provided to monitor for severe toxicity.

(Choice D)  The physician should carefully document in the patient's chart that the risks of the patient's intended treatment have been explained and that continued care to monitor for toxicity is needed.  However, asking the patient to sign a written consent or waiver is not necessary because the physician is neither providing nor advocating for the treatment.

Educational objective:
When discussing a patient's use of nonstandard therapies that are known to be harmful, the physician should clearly explain the risks to the patient.  If the patient insists on using such therapies, the physician should schedule close follow-up to strengthen the therapeutic alliance and monitor for toxicity.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Complementary and alternative medicine

answerChoiceList.choice: "I am not comfortable with you taking ephedra, but if you would like, I can transfer you to another provider who is more comfortable with this supplement."
"I don't recommend starting ephedra, but I'm available to talk about prescription weight loss medications if you change your mind in the future."
"If you start taking ephedra, I would like to see you for regular follow-up visits so that I can monitor for any adverse effects."
"It seems you plan to start taking ephedra; will you please sign a form saying that you understand the risks of taking this supplement?"
"Supplements are more commonly used at weight loss treatment centers; perhaps you should look into getting a consultation at one."

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Common herbal dietary supplement-drug interactions.
Online marketing of ephedra weight loss supplements: labeling and marketing compliance with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration ban on ephedra.

questionList.questionText: A 76-year-old woman comes to the office for follow-up after being seen in the emergency department for a fall.  While walking to the bathroom at night, the patient tripped on her cane, which she uses intermittently for long-standing knee osteoarthritis, and fell to the floor.  She was unable to rise for several minutes following the fall.  Evaluation in the emergency department revealed no fracture.  Before this episode, the patient had sustained 2 similar falls at home in the past year, one while going downstairs and the other while walking outside.  Each time, she did not sustain any major injuries or seek care from a medical provider.  The patient lives alone and has a caregiver who assists her with daily meal preparation and grocery shopping.  Medical history also includes hypertension, for which she takes an ACE inhibitor.  Blood pressure is 142/87 mm Hg sitting and 141/79 mm Hg standing.  Pulse is 83/min.  The patient is alert and fully oriented.  Muscle strength is globally decreased in the upper and lower extremities.  Gait is slow but without evidence of ataxia or a limp.  Examination of the heart and lungs is normal.  Which of the following should be performed next to reduce this patient's risk for falls?
questionList.explanationText:
Falls in older adults

Overview

  • Leading cause of injury, morbidity, mortality

Risk factors

  • History of fall
  • Sensory & cognitive disturbance
  • Chronic disease (eg, T2DM, arthritis, CVD)
  • Medications (eg, neuroleptics, antidepressants, vasodilators)

Outpatient prevention

  • Screening: musculoskeletal (eg, "get up & go" test*), vision, hearing, bone density, orthostasis
  • Medication & home safety review
  • Correction of vitamin D deficiency (in select patients)
  • Supervised exercise program

Inpatient prevention

  • Assess fall risk & customize strategies to patient's specific risk factors
  • Optimize environment (eg, minimize furniture, lower the bed, place in direct view of nurses if high risk)
  • Perform frequent checks on high-risk patients
  • Avoid restraints & overreliance on fall alert systems

*Ask the patient to rise from a chair & walk briskly to the end of the room.  Time & patient difficulty in this test predict the risk of falling.

CVD = cardiovascular disease; T2DM = type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Falls are a major cause of injury in older adults (eg, age >65), resulting in injury, prolonged immobilization, and functional decline.  This patient has multiple fall risk factors, including prior history of a fall, decreased muscle strength, and history of a chronic condition (eg, hypertension, osteoarthritis).

All patients who have fallen should undergo a multifactorial risk assessment that includes screening for sensory disturbances, a major underlying contributor to fall risk in the elderly population.  For example, age-related declines in proprioception affect balance, leaving patients with increased reliance on visual input.  As a result, diminished visual acuity can substantially elevate overall fall risk.  In addition, age-related eye conditions (eg, macular degeneration, cataracts) can reduce dark adaptation, increasing risk for falls in low-light conditions.  Therefore, all patients who sustain a fall should have visual acuity screening with a dilated eye examination and receive appropriate corrective eyewear or prevention interventions (eg, surgical treatment of cataracts, nutritional supplementation for macular degeneration).

In patients who have sustained previous falls, supervised balance and strength training and a home safety assessment (typically performed by an occupational therapist) are also recommended to further reduce risk for subsequent falls.

(Choices A and B)  Holter monitoring is rarely indicated in average-risk elderly patients who sustain falls in the absence of concerning symptoms (eg, history of palpitations, frequent syncope).  Carotid artery stenosis is also not a typical cause of falls.  Sensory function (eg, balance, vision) should be tested first.

(Choice C)  Although vasodilators (eg, calcium channel blockers) may increase fall risk in some patients, discontinuation of this patient's ACE inhibitor is not recommended given her hypertension and lack of orthostasis.

(Choice D)  Assistive devices (eg, canes, scooters, walkers) may be needed in select cases.  However, the specific type of device should be identified only after multifactorial assessment (eg, physical therapy evaluation, home safety assessment) is completed.  Use of assistive devices without adequate training or assessment has been linked to increased risks (eg, tripping over the device, muscle atrophy from disuse).

(Choice E)  This patient may eventually require increased assistance if she experiences further functional declines or falls.  However, preservation of independence is often highly desired by patients, and attempts should first be made to screen for correctable contributors to fall risk.

Educational objective:
Age-related declines in proprioception lead to increased reliance on visual input, and diminished visual acuity can substantially elevate fall risk in dark settings.  Patients who sustain falls should undergo a multifactorial fall risk assessment that includes screening and correction of deficits in balance, strength, and vision.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Falls

answerChoiceList.choice: 24-hour Holter monitoring
Carotid duplex ultrasonography
Discontinuation of the ACE inhibitor
Prescription for a motorized scooter
Referral to an assisted living facility
Visual acuity testing

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Ageing vision and falls: a review.

questionList.questionText: A 65-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is admitted to the intensive care unit with worsening dyspnea.  Shortly after admission, the patient suffers a cardiac arrest; despite intensive resuscitation measures, he does not recover and is declared dead 15 minutes later.  The patient's family is brought to the bedside and team members provide emotional support.  An internal medicine resident, who was a part of the patient's treatment team, asks the attending physician if it would be possible to practice intubating and placing a central venous line on the deceased patient in order to fulfill training procedure requirements for residency.  Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?
questionList.explanationText:
Residents must develop life-saving skills and procedure competency (eg, intubation, central venous line placement) during training; however, suitable practice opportunities are not always readily available as need is unpredictable.  In addition, potential risk of harm to patients if done incorrectly further limits possibilities.  As a result, the use of recently deceased patient bodies has become common in developing resident proficiency by providing opportunities for procedure mastery prior to performing on living patients in urgent or emergent settings.

However, the use of recently deceased patient bodies for resident training raises ethical issues, especially the issue of obtaining consent.  Ideally, consent should be obtained from the patient prior to death and through hospital personnel not directly involved in patient care to reduce influence on patient voluntariness.  If not possible due to patient death, consent should be obtained from family as long as it is not against a patient's previously expressed wishes and an appropriate amount of time has elapsed so as not to escalate family emotional pain or intrude on their immediate grieving period (Choices A and E).  Yet, even after time has elapsed, if there is high likelihood of significant escalation of family member distress, they should not be approached for consent and the pursuit should be dropped.

Further, residents performing procedures on deceased patients should do so under direct supervision and with structured teaching from attendings.  This oversight allows for additional safeguarding to maintain the dignity of the patient and respect for family through clearly defined training objectives while limiting unnecessary harm to the body.

(Choices B and D)  Training procedures on recently deceased patients should always be performed under direct attending supervision; however, receiving care in a training facility does not imply informed consent.  Before any procedure is performed by an attending or trainee on a deceased patient's body, consent must be obtained, either from the patient prior to death or posthumously from family members.

Educational objective:
Permission must be obtained from the family (or from the patient prior to death) before procedures can be performed on a newly deceased patient for training purposes.  An appropriate amount of time should elapse before family is approached so as not to unduly escalate their grief.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Informed consent

answerChoiceList.choice: Allow the resident to initiate an informed consent discussion with the family about performing training procedures on the patient
Allow the resident to proceed with the training procedures under direct supervision since the patient was receiving care in a teaching facility
Discuss with the resident that it would not be appropriate to ask for the family's consent to perform training procedures at this time
Inform the family that the patient was being treated at a teaching hospital and will undergo training procedures by the resident under direct supervision
Initiate an informed consent discussion with the family about whether the resident can perform training procedures on the patient

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Teaching without harm: the ethics of performing posthumous procedures on the newly deceased.

questionList.questionText: A hospital is opening a new primary care clinic on the outskirts of a diverse, major metropolitan city with numerous non-English-speaking, immigrant, and refugee populations.  Approximately one-third of the city's population speaks Spanish, and one-fourth identifies as Black.  10% of the clinic providers belong to various minority ethnic backgrounds.  The medical director is aware of significant chronic-disease–related health disparities affecting Black and Spanish-speaking patients, who are more likely to experience severe disease and preventable disease complications.  Which of the following organizational actions is most likely to improve provider health care communication for patients of minority backgrounds?
questionList.explanationText:
Cross-cultural care improves provider-patient communication and health outcomes, especially for minority populations that experience significant health disparities (eg, preventable differences in health linked to demographic attributes).  Cross-cultural care reflects high-value care principles common to all populations, including:

  • Patient-centeredness:  identifying the patient's values and aligning care with the patient's priorities

  • Cultural sensitivity:  exploring the patient's cultural beliefs and understanding how sociocultural background influences perceptions of health decisions

  • Enhanced communication:  addressing language barriers (eg, use of interpreter services) and tailoring communication styles (eg, adjusting eye contact, addressing family) to a patient's preferences

Cross-cultural care emphasizes the importance of avoiding stereotyping, since minority groups (eg, Black) comprise a variety of subcultures (eg, Caribbean, African) and patients' preferences vary within groups.  For example, although some minority patients may prefer family involvement or minority providers, providers should avoid assuming that all minority patients share this preference and explore individual patient preferences (Choices A and D).

(Choice B)  Providing translated materials can be effective as a complement to patient-centered counseling.  However, training providers to actively deliver patient-centered, cross-cultural care represents a more comprehensive and versatile approach that can improve communication outcomes across multiple, diverse populations (eg, immigrants, refugee groups).

(Choice C)  Providing information about cultural beliefs of specific ethnic populations can be useful but represents a more passive approach, addresses only certain ethnicities, and may promote stereotyping given the diversity of beliefs within ethnic groups.  Cross-cultural care is more likely to improve outcomes across patient populations because it promotes learning about individual patient beliefs and tailoring communication accordingly.

Educational objective:
Cross-cultural care improves health outcomes and communication in diverse populations.  It involves components of high-value care common to all populations, including patient-centeredness (ie, exploring an individual patient's beliefs), avoidance of stereotyping, and cultural sensitivity (responding to a patient's sociocultural paradigm).
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Cultural considerations

answerChoiceList.choice: Advise clinicians to routinely involve family members when caring for minority patients
Develop patient educational materials in multiple languages, including Spanish
Provide information to clinicians on the health beliefs of Black and Hispanic/Latino cultures
Schedule non-English-speaking and minority patients with providers of minority backgrounds
Train providers on methods to identify and align care delivery with patient preferences

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Patient-centered care: the key to cultural competence.

questionList.questionText:
The following vignette applies to the next 2 items.  The items in the set must be answered in sequential order.  Once you click Proceed to Next Item, you will not be able to add or change an answer.

Item 1 of 2

A 31-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to abdominal pain.  The patient tells the triage nurse that he is experiencing severe pain.  The physician, who has never before seen this patient, reviews the chart and finds that the patient has come to the emergency department for abdominal pain almost weekly over the past 3 months.  Each time, the patient was discharged after receiving intravenous analgesics to resolve the pain.  The physician also reviews the physical examination and diagnostic tests performed by previous providers that did not show obvious abdominal pathology.  Prior to seeing the patient, the physician automatically narrows the differential diagnosis for abdominal pain based on information and prior diagnoses found in the chart.  The physician's behavior most closely reflects which of the following cognitive biases?
questionList.explanationText:
Common cognitive errors in medicine

Type of bias

Definition

Example

Anchoring

  • Fixating on initial impressions to make a diagnosis
  • Related to confirmation bias & premature closure
  • Burning throat pain diagnosed as acid reflux despite weight loss
  • Correct diagnosis is lung malignancy

Availability

  • Allowing recently seen or memorable (high-stakes) cases to sway diagnosis
  • Dyspnea diagnosed as influenza during peak influenza season
  • Correct diagnosis is pulmonary embolism

Confirmation

  • Emphasizing evidence that supports presumed diagnosis & overlooking information that supports other diagnoses
  • Related to anchoring bias
  • Burning throat pain after eating spicy food diagnosed as acid reflux despite weight loss
  • Correct diagnosis is malignancy

Framing

  • Allowing diagnostic approach to be influenced by context & presentation of information
  • Abdominal pain diagnosed as opioid withdrawal in patient described as drug seeking
  • Correct diagnosis is bowel obstruction

This physician has not yet evaluated the patient but has narrowed the differential diagnosis based on information in the chart.  Framing bias is a type of cognitive bias caused by excessive influence of contextual or prior information (eg, chart documentation).  Framing bias frequently affects the evaluation of patients with multiple visits in busy settings (eg, emergency department) and leads to an incomplete differential diagnosis.

Although reviewing existing chart information prior to seeing a patient is generally helpful and does not by itself constitute error, overreliance on this information (eg, formulating a differential diagnosis before seeing the patient) can cause the physician to miss potentially serious etiologies of symptoms.

(Choice A)  Availability bias describes the excessive influence of commonly seen (ie, "available") etiologies in determining a diagnosis (eg, attributing the cause of dyspnea to influenza during a busy winter season).  This physician's diagnostic approach is most closely influenced by this patient's chart information.

(Choice B)  Confirmation bias occurs when a physician relies too much on findings that support (ie, "confirm") a presumed diagnosis but discounts findings suggestive of an alternate diagnosis; it typically occurs during examination and workup of the patient.  This physician's overreliance on prior chart information and forming a diagnostic opinion before seeing the patient is more consistent with framing bias.

(Choice D)  Selection bias refers to errors in the selection of participants (eg, enrolling research subjects) and is not a type of cognitive bias.

(Choice E)  Triage cueing results when the diagnostic evaluation is overly influenced by the patient's triage category.  For example, a physician may miss concerning signs in a patient who is triaged as low acuity by another staff member.  This patient's triage status is not given; rather, chart information is more directly linked to the physician's incomplete diagnostic approach.

Educational objective:
Framing bias is characterized by the formation of an incomplete differential diagnosis due to the influence of contextual or prior information (eg, past evaluations).  It frequently affects the evaluation of patients with multiple visits in busy settings and can cause a physician to miss potentially serious disease.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Patient safety

answerChoiceList.choice: Availability bias
Confirmation bias
Framing bias
Selection bias
Triage cueing

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Review of the basics of cognitive error in emergency medicine: still no easy answers.
Cognitive biases associated with medical decisions: a systematic review.

questionList.questionText:
Item 2 of 2
When reviewing patient charts, the medical director of the emergency department sees that the patient has received multiple CT scans of the abdomen during his visits to the emergency department (over 10 CT scans in the past 3 months).  The director is concerned that, in many cases, CT scans were administered without clear clinical indication, especially when another, lower-cost test may have sufficed.  The director discusses this concern with all physicians involved in caring for the patient.  The physicians report that they did not feel the CT scans were necessary based on their clinical judgment but were motivated to order them due to fear about possible malpractice liability in case they missed a serious diagnosis.  Which of the following interventions is most likely to address this feedback and reduce the unnecessary use of CT scans?
questionList.explanationText:
