Defensive medicine refers to provision of clinical services primarily to reduce physician liability without significant benefit to the patient.  It can result in overuse (eg, unnecessary use of CT scans), with worse patient outcomes (eg, cumulative radiation exposure) and higher costs.

Liability concerns are often effectively addressed by implementing clinical pathways or practice guidelines.  These guidelines are typically established by major specialty societies (eg, American College of Radiology) and specify standardized, evidence-based recommendations for common conditions (eg, when CT scans are indicated in the evaluation of abdominal pain).  Such guidelines serve as a broadly recognized standard of care; therefore, physicians adhering to them are more likely to be protected from liability (because malpractice typically involves care that deviates from a reasonable clinical standard).

(Choice B)  Enhancing malpractice coverage does not address physician's psychologic discomfort or fear associated with litigation and is unlikely to reduce practice of defensive medicine.

(Choice C)  Continuing education programs on the harms of overuse may be helpful but are less beneficial than providing physicians with a defensible standard of care.

(Choice D)  Requiring radiology approval for imaging requests can reduce costs but is inefficient and impractical in a busy emergency department and would not address liability concerns.

(Choice E)  Awareness of and training on cognitive patterns (ie, metacognition) is an important mechanism to reduce diagnostic errors associated with cognitive bias.  However, the physicians in this case were already cognitively aware that repeated CT scans were unnecessary but performed them anyway due to litigation fear; this is more consistent with defensive medicine rather than cognitive bias.  Establishing an evidence-based standard of care (ie, through clinical practice guidelines) more directly addresses malpractice liability and therefore is more likely to reduce overuse.

Educational objective:
Defensive medicine refers to clinical services that are intended primarily to reduce physician liability without providing significant benefit to the patient.  It can result in overuse and worse patient outcomes.  Implementing evidence-based clinical pathways or practice guidelines can minimize physician liability and reduce defensive medicine.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Healthcare quality

answerChoiceList.choice: Implementing clinical pathways for abdominal pain throughout the department
Obtaining enhanced malpractice coverage for emergency department physicians
Providing physicians with continuing education courses on harms resulting from unnecessary imaging
Requiring radiologists to review and approve orders for imaging tests involving ionizing radiation
Training clinicians to understand how cognitive patterns can cause diagnostic errors

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Physicians' fears of malpractice lawsuits are not assuaged by tort reforms.
Defensive medicine among high-risk specialist physicians in a volatile malpractice environment.
Defensive medicine: a case and review of its status and possible solutions.

questionList.questionText: A 78-year-old woman with a history of mild cognitive impairment, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypertension is brought to the emergency department by her daughter after sustaining a fall.  The patient's daughter, a full-time nurse who visits her mother daily, found her confused and lying on the ground.  The daughter checked her mother's blood sugar and found it to be 55 mg/dL.  After the patient drank some apple juice, the confusion quickly improved.  The patient takes 10 different medications, including insulin and an antidepressant, which was recently prescribed by her neurologist for symptoms of apathy.  Temperature is 36.7 C (98.1 F), blood pressure is 127/86 mm Hg, and pulse is 78/min.  She is alert and oriented to self, time, and place.  Physical examination shows tenderness of the right ankle but is otherwise normal.  Repeat fingerstick glucose is 85 mg/dL.  The patient is treated for ankle sprain and can ambulate with a cane and her ankle in a boot.  The pain is controlled.  The patient lives alone in a single-story home, is independent with activities of daily living, and was seen in the emergency department 5 months ago for a similar episode.  She requests to go home, but her daughter expresses concern about her mother's ability to take medications as prescribed.  In addition to close primary care follow-up, which of the following interventions is most recommended to prevent future recurrence of falls in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Home health care

Overview

  • Health services provided by skilled HCWs (eg, nursing, PT/OT, SW) in the home
  • Covered by Medicare if patient is homebound & has skilled health needs

Uses

  • Medically stable for discharge but homebound & requiring intermittent monitoring
  • High risk of adverse events (eg, fall risk, complex medication regimen)
  • Skilled nursing needs (eg, wounds, physical rehabilitation)

Benefits

  • Promote patient mental health, autonomy & independence
  • Reduce risk of hospital readmission & length of hospitalization (eg, fewer nosocomial infections)
  • Decrease health care spending (ie, less expensive than skilled nursing facility)

HCWs = health care workers; OT = occupational therapy; PT = physical therapy; SW = social work.

Falls are a major cause of morbidity in the elderly.  This patient, who likely fell due to hypoglycemia from insulin use, is now medically stable for discharge (ie, ambulates with assistance, is normoglycemic).  However, she has risk factors for future falls, including new ankle injury, complex medication regimen, previous fall history, age, and cognitive impairment.  Fall risk reduction for this patient is best achieved through home health care, which describes home-based, interdisciplinary care (eg, physical therapy, nursing) provided by skilled professionals (eg, nurses, licensed social workers).

As a form of care coordination (ie, facilitating safe transition of care), home health care increases health care quality (eg, reducing hospital readmissions and medication errors).  It is preferred for this patient due to the following:

  • She will be home-bound from ankle injury and continue to have medical needs, including physical therapy and medication management (eg, safe insulin administration) to reduce hypoglycemia risk.
  • She can receive a home safety assessment (eg, by an occupational therapist) to identify environmental fall risk factors (eg, throw rugs, no handrails in bathtub).
  • She lives independently and expresses preference to return home; her autonomy, independence, and mental health can be promoted safely through home health care.  When possible, optimizing home safety and engaging patients directly are preferred to relying on visiting family members, such as the patient's daughter who has a full-time job (Choice C).

(Choice A)  Admitting this patient when she is medically stable for discharge is not recommended because it increases her risk for adverse events (eg, nosocomial infections) and represents inefficient resource use.  Cognitive assessments can be performed in the home and at follow-up appointments.

(Choice D)  Skilled nursing facilities are appropriate when patients cannot live at home or require continuous monitoring (eg, post-stroke rehabilitation, severe cognitive impairment).  Although this patient may eventually require a skilled nursing facility if her cognitive function worsens, she currently has only mild cognitive impairment and minor ankle injury.  Therefore, primary care follow-up and home health physical therapy is preferred to reduce her fall risk while preserving her independence.

Educational objective:
Home health care, a form of care coordination (eg, safe transition of care), provides home-based, interdisciplinary health services (eg, physical therapy, home safety assessment, management of complex medication regimen) by skilled professionals (eg, nurses, social workers).  It improves safety (eg, reducing fall risk in the elderly) and health care quality while maintaining patient independence, autonomy, and engagement.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Healthcare quality

answerChoiceList.choice: Admit the patient to the hospital for cognitive and functional assessment
Arrange for the patient to receive home health care
Request that the patient's daughter administer her medications at home
Transfer the patient to a skilled nursing facility until her ankle heals

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Patient safety and quality in home health care.
Assessment and management of fall risk in primary care settings.

questionList.questionText: A 42-year-old man comes to the primary care office to establish care.  The patient has asthma but has not seen a physician in several years because he did not have insurance.  He now has a high-deductible insurance plan offered by his new employer.  The patient has been experiencing increasing shortness of breath and is using a friend's spare albuterol inhaler at least twice a day, which improves his symptoms.  He has smoked 2 or 3 cigarettes several days a week for 15 years and currently is not interested in quitting.  Blood pressure is 135/89 mm Hg and pulse is 77/min.  Oxygen saturation is 98% on room air.  BMI is 34 kg/m2.  Physical examination reveals mild expiratory wheezing but is otherwise normal.  The physician considers initiating various interventions to improve control of asthma.  Which of the following best represents a patient-centered approach to manage this patient's asthma?
questionList.explanationText:
Patient-centered care

Overview

  • Incorporate patient values into medical decisions
  • Emphasize outcomes important to patients
  • Improve health care quality & patient satisfaction

Examples

  • Shared decision-making between patient & physician
  • Decision aids to assist patients in understanding options
  • Care coordination to streamline chronic condition management

Patient-centered care (PCC) improves outcomes by considering factors (eg, costs, beliefs) valued by patients, including factors outside the immediate clinical setting.  For example, patient adherence to treatment is frequently affected by medication affordability.  PCC can guide management of conditions (eg, asthma) for which available treatment options have widely divergent out-of-pocket costs by emphasizing shared decision-making, in which physicians discuss relative benefits of acceptable treatments and elicit patients' preferences in selecting therapy.

Insurance plans often require patient out-of-pocket spending (eg, co-payments, or patient's share of the cost) for prescription medications; such spending can vary significantly among various therapies (eg, generic versus brand-name drug).  This patient has an insurance plan with a high deductible (ie, amount of patient spending required before insurance coverage starts), typically entailing higher patient spending on health care services.  Therefore, considering out-of-pocket costs in selecting treatment is likely to reduce barriers to care, improve treatment adherence, and optimize long-term outcomes.

(Choice A)  Biweekly clinic follow-up is excessive and likely to be burdensome for this patient (eg, requiring work absences, additional visit co-pays).  If frequent clinical contact is desired, alternate communication modalities (eg, electronic portal, telephone follow-up) may be equally effective and more acceptable to the patient.

(Choice C)  Nicotine replacement therapy is most effective when patients are motivated and interested in quitting smoking (ie, contemplative or action stage).  This patient is not interested in quitting (ie, precontemplative stage); therefore, nicotine replacement is premature, does not reflect his preferences, and risks alienating him.

(Choice D)  Obesity can aggravate asthma, and weight loss can facilitate better long-term control.  However, this patient has increasing symptoms and his medication regimen should be optimized first.

(Choice E)  Validated clinical guidelines are useful for optimizing patient management.  However, many chronic conditions, including asthma, have multiple acceptable treatment strategies.  In such cases, PCC emphasizes tailoring care to the specific patient situation.  Medication affordability may necessitate substituting first-line treatment with an acceptable, evidence-supported alternate (eg, second-line generic medication) to optimize adherence.

Educational objective:
Patient-centered care (PCC) improves outcomes by considering factors valued by patients.  Treatment adherence is frequently affected by medication affordability; PCC emphasizes shared decision-making, in which physicians consider treatment costs, discuss relative benefits of acceptable options, and elicit patients' preferences in selecting therapy.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Healthcare quality

answerChoiceList.choice: Arranging biweekly clinical follow-up to assess symptom control
Considering out-of-pocket costs for specific asthma medications
Counseling the patient to attempt nicotine replacement therapy
Counseling the patient to lose weight to improve symptoms
Prescribing the first-line treatment listed in current guidelines

questionList.questionText: A resident physician is completing a pediatric intensive care unit (ICU) rotation at a busy academic medical center.  The resident is highly engaged in the care of patients, frequently visiting them at the bedside, communicating with nurses, and guiding families through difficult treatment decisions.  The ICU is frequently busy; several patients under the resident's care experience prolonged illness despite complex interventions, with some dying unexpectedly.  Several weeks into the rotation, the attending physician notices that the resident appears withdrawn during rounds, often forgetting or being unfamiliar with details of patients' histories.  The attending physician meets with the resident privately to discuss these concerns.  The resident becomes tearful and states, "It is exhausting to see so many patients suffering and dying.  Even when I'm at home, I stay up at night thinking about my patients and whether I'm failing at my job.  Maybe I would be better off withdrawing from this program."  The resident is offered appropriate support resources.  In addition, which of the following system-based interventions is recommended to reduce the future risk of this occurrence in resident physicians?
questionList.explanationText:
This resident, who has had prolonged exposure to dying patients, has evidence of burnout, characterized by emotional exhaustion (eg, insomnia, tearfulness), depersonalization (eg, appearing withdrawn), and low sense of personal accomplishment (eg, failure at the job).

Burnout commonly affects physicians in the intensive care unit, who have frequent exposure to death and severe illness but often receive little support for grief associated with caring for dying patients.  Residents are vulnerable to perceiving untimely death as a personal failure, and have few protected opportunities to discuss emotionally distressing episodes.  Interdisciplinary debriefing sessions ("grief rounds"), which are dedicated to discussing psychosocial aspects of patient care from the provider's perspective, are associated with improved physician well-being and coping skills.

Grief rounds are conducted in specific settings (eg, intensive care unit), with protected time given to residents to attend regularly (eg, biweekly, monthly).  They are characterized by the following:

  • Team-based structure (eg, physician, psychotherapist, chaplain)

  • Interactive format, which elicits open sharing of experiences and reduces perceived stigma associated with expressing emotional distress

  • Focus on the caregiver's experience associated with loss and caring for ill patients

(Choice A)  Improving resident comfort in communicating with patients and families is recommended, but does not directly assist physicians' distress associated with difficult patient experiences.

(Choice B)  Access to psychiatrists should be made available to residents for any mental health needs and management of burnout.  However, passive distribution of psychiatrist contact information is less effective in preventing burnout compared to active participation in grief rounds, which are directly incorporated into patient care activities and do not require additional cost or time off.

(Choice D)  Fatigue can increase risk for burnout, and duty hour and sleep restrictions are associated with reduced fatigue and improved learning and safety.  While beneficial, they do not directly address emotional reactions associated with patient care, including grief and insomnia that persist during days off.

(Choice E)  Assessing prevalence of depression can guide general management of a residency program but does not help individual residents cope with job-related grief.

Educational objective:
Physicians caring for critically ill patients frequently experience emotional distress, which can cause burnout.  Interdisciplinary debriefing sessions dedicated to discussing psychosocial aspects of patient care are associated with improved physician well-being and ability to cope with distress.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: End of life care

answerChoiceList.choice: Conducting interactive training exercises every year to improve residents' skills in delivering difficult news
Creating and distributing a resident wellness handbook containing local psychiatrist contacts
Holding rounds every two weeks dedicated to discussing psychosocial aspects of caring for critically ill patients
Increasing resident duty hour restrictions and length of mandatory sleep periods
Organizing a quarterly anonymous screening of residents for symptoms of depression

questionMappingReferencesList.title: The critical nature of addressing burnout prevention: results from the critical care societies collaborative's national summit and survey on prevention and management of burnout in the ICU.
Monthly "grief rounds" to improve residents' experience and decrease burnout in a medical intensive care unit rotation.

flashCardList.frontText:
Adolescent nonsuicidal self-injury

Features

  • Deliberate injury with no intent to die
  • Methods: cutting, burning, scratching
  • Typical onset: age 12-14

Function/purpose

  • Regulate distressing emotions
  • Punish self
  • Elicit support or allow for avoidance (eg, missing school)

Management

  • Psychotherapy
  • Psychiatric evaluation, medications for comorbid conditions

Confidentiality vs safety

  • Consider informing parents if any of the following are present:
    • Suicidal ideation
    • Impairment, distress
    • Multiple episodes, escalating frequency
    • Single episode with serious medical risks (eg, use of razor, sutures)
